name: Arianna
bio:
Arianna Fontana OMRI (born April 14, 1990) is an Italian short track speed skater, who has won eight Olympic medals, among these a gold in the 500m short track at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. Her medal haul following the 2018 Games made her the female short track skater with the most Olympic medals, and tied her with male skaters Apolo Ohno and Viktor An. It also made her the Italian sportswoman with the second highest number of Winter Olympic medals, behind Stefania Belmondo. She specialises in the 500 m event. She is nicknamed La Freccia Bionda (The Blonde Arrow).

Biography
=======
Fontana started skating at the age of four, following in the footsteps of her brother Alessandro, initially on roller skates before switching to ice skating. She first trained in Lanzada until the rink there closed, when she switched her training base to Bormio.

Fontana made her international championship debut at the 2006 European Short Track Speed Skating Championships in Krynica-Zdrój, where she took the overall silver medal. At the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, she won bronze in the 3000 m relay. She placed 11th in the 500m and 6th in the 1000 m. The relay medal was the first for Italy in short track speed skating: at 15 years of age, Fontana became the youngest Italian to win a Winter Olympic medal. Following the 2006 Games, Fontana and her relay team-mates were appointed Knights of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic.

At the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, she won a bronze medal in the 500 metre event, was eliminated in the semifinals of the 1500 metre event, and was eliminated in the quarterfinals of the 1000 metre event. Her 500m bronze made her the first Italian to take an individual Olympic medal in short track.

Fontano began dating Italian-American skater Anthony Lobello Jr. in 2012: the couple were engaged the following year and married in May 2014 in Colico. The couple split their time between homes in Valtellina, Courmayeur and Tallahassee, Florida.

At the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, she was upgraded from a bronze to a silver medal in the 500 m event after colliding with British skater Elise Christie. Christie was disqualified after causing a crash in the final. She won a bronze medal in the 1500 m event and in the Team-event, and was disqualified in the 1000 m event. Following the Games, Lobello began coaching Fontana following his retirement from competition. The following year Fontana took her first title at the World Short Track Speed Skating Championships, winning the gold in the 1500m and taking the overall silver.

In October 2017, Fontana was named as Italy's flag bearer for the opening ceremony of the 2018 Winter Olympics in PyeongChang, South Korea. She was the first short track skater to be selected as flag bearer for the Italian Olympic team and the second flag bearer from the Italian Ice Sports Federation, after Carolina Kostner. She won her first Olympic gold medal there, in the 500 m event.She was the first European to win a 500 m Olympic gold. She also won silver in the team event and bronze in the 1000 m event, becoming the woman with most medals in the sport. It also meant that she had won Olympic medals at every contested distance.

name: Fermín
bio:
**Fermín Cacho Ruiz**  (born 16 February 1969) is a  [Spanish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain "Spain")  [track and field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field")  athlete, winner of the  [1500 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1500_metres "1500 metres")  at the  [1992 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics").

Born in  [Ágreda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%81greda "Ágreda"), Spain, Cacho had an enviable competitive record in the 1500 m, but it wasn't until late in his career that he produced a time of corresponding quality.

Cacho's first notable result came in 1990, when he finished second in the 1500 m at the  [European Indoor Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1990_European_Indoor_Championships_in_Athletics "1990 European Indoor Championships in Athletics")  in  [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow"). At the 1991  [World Indoor Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1991_IAAF_World_Indoor_Championships "1991 IAAF World Indoor Championships")  in  [Seville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seville "Seville"), Cacho finished again second in the 1500 m, behind  [Noureddine Morceli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noureddine_Morceli "Noureddine Morceli").

At the  [Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  in  [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), Cacho was not considered a serious gold medal threat. But the Olympic 1500 m final was run at a very pedestrian pace, and Cacho positioned himself perfectly in the final lap, and outsprinted his rivals, with an unprecedented last lap of 50.6 seconds, to win the  [gold medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_medal "Gold medal")  in 3:40.12.

In 1993 at  [Stuttgart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart")  in  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1993 World Championships in Athletics"), Cacho finished second, but took the 1500 m title at the  [European Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994_European_Championships_in_Athletics#Track "1994 European Championships in Athletics")  in  [Helsinki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki")  in the next year. In  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1995 World Championships in Athletics")  at  [Gothenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothenburg "Gothenburg"), Cacho only finished in eighth place.

After a relatively lean year in 1995, Cacho was back to his best in the early part of the 1996 season, leading up to the  [Olympic Games in Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics"). Although Cacho was the defending  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  1500 m champion, the final in  [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia "Atlanta, Georgia")  was considered to be a match race between Morceli and  [Hicham El Guerrouj](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj "Hicham El Guerrouj"), who had filled the first two places at the previous year's World Championships. Approaching the completion of the third lap, Morceli was leading from El Guerrouj, when suddenly the Moroccan tripped and fell. In taking evasive action, Cacho was forced to leap over the fallen El Guerrouj, in a manoeuvre which he later estimated had lost him 5 metres of ground to Morceli, who had commenced his final lap sprint for the finish. Cacho chased Morceli around the last lap, but was unable to catch him. In the end Morceli won by 5 metres from the second-placed Cacho.

At the  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1997 World Championships in Athletics")  in  [Athens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athens "Athens")  in 1997, Cacho won a  [silver medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_medal "Silver medal")  again, and at the end of the same season he finally managed to run his world class time, when he finished second at the 1500 m behind El Guerrouj with a time of 3:28.95, which moved him to third on the all-time world list behind Morceli and El Guerrouj. He won the  [bronze medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronze_medal "Bronze medal")  at the  [1998 European Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_European_Championships_in_Athletics#Track "1998 European Championships in Athletics")  in  [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest "Budapest"), and finished fourth in the  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1999 World Championships in Athletics")  at Seville in 1999. Cacho suffered an  [Achilles' tendon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_tendon "Achilles' tendon")  injury in 2000, causing him to miss the opportunity to add to his Olympic gold and silver medals at  [2000 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics")  in  [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney").

He held the  [European record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_European_records_in_athletics "List of European records in athletics")  at 1500 m with a time of 3:28.95 for 16 years (1997–2013), until  [Mo Farah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah "Mo Farah")  broke it with a time of 3:28.81.

name: Evelyn
bio:
**Evelyn Ashford**  (born April 15, 1957 in  [Shreveport, Louisiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shreveport,_Louisiana "Shreveport, Louisiana")) is an American retired  [track and field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field")  athlete, the 1984  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  champion in the  [100-meter dash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100-meter_dash "100-meter dash"). She ran under the 11-second barrier over 30 times and was the first to run under 11 seconds in an Olympic Games.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-sports-reference.com-2)

As a 19-year-old, Ashford finished 5th in the 100 m event at the  [1976 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics "1976 Summer Olympics"). After beating the World Record holders in the 100 m and 200 m in 1979 at the World Cup of Track and Field in Montreal, Ashford was one of the potential medalists for the  [1980 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics"), but these Games were  [boycotted by the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics_boycott "1980 Summer Olympics boycott"). Evelyn also tore a quad muscle in May, and was out for the rest of the season.

Ashford was ranked No. 1 in the world by  _[Track & Field News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%26_Field_News "Track & Field News")_  over 100 metres in 1979 and 1981,[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-T&FN100-3)  and over 200 metres in 1981.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-T&FN200-4)  She also was named Track and Field News "Athlete of the Year" twice, in 1981 and 1984[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-5)

She would again win the sprint double, at the World Cup of Track and Field in Rome, in 1981.

On July 3, 1983, she set her first World Record (be it at altitude) for the 100 metres, running 10.79 seconds at the National Sports Festival in  [Colorado Springs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_Springs,_Colorado "Colorado Springs, Colorado"),  [Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado "Colorado")  and was one of the favourites to win the 100 metre title at the  [inaugural World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1983 World Championships in Athletics")  in  [Helsinki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"). In the final, however, she pulled a  [hamstring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamstring "Hamstring")  muscle and fell. The other main favourite,  [Marlies Göhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marlies_G%C3%B6hr "Marlies Göhr")  of  [East Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany")  (who had already beaten Ashford earlier that year) went on to win.

At the  [1984 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_Summer_Olympics "1984 Summer Olympics"), Ashford had a chance to win a gold medal. However, she had to withdraw from the 200 m heats with a minor injury. She competed in the  [100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1984_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_100_metres "Athletics at the 1984 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metres"), winning the event in a new Olympic Record of 10.97 secs. As the anchor runner for 4 × 100 m relay team, she won a second gold medal. In the absence of World Champions and world record holders East Germany, the US team clocked one of the fastest times in history and won by the biggest margin ever at an Olympics, 1.12 seconds.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-sports-reference.com-2)

Later in the season, she finally defeated her main rival Göhr at the  [Weltklasse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weltklasse "Weltklasse")  meeting in  [Zürich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"),  [Switzerland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland"). The race saw Ashford make up half a metre or so over Göhr and lower her own World Record to 10.76 secs.  [See the race](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Mdu3fQXBUE)  on  [YouTube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube "YouTube")  That race proved to be Ashford's personal record. It still ranks as the No. 8 Individual all-time[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-6)  Ashford, unsurprisingly, regained her No. 1  _Track & Field News_  ranking.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-T&FN100-3)

At the  [1988 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics"), she was the flag bearer for the United States team at the Opening Ceremony. She was beaten in the 100 m by  [Florence Griffith Joyner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Griffith_Joyner "Florence Griffith Joyner"), who had broken her World Record earlier in the season at the  [Olympic Trials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_United_States_Olympic_Trials_(track_and_field) "1988 United States Olympic Trials (track and field)"). In the  [4 × 100 m relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1988_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_x_100_metre_relay "Athletics at the 1988 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 x 100 metre relay")  she again ran the final leg, winning her third Olympic gold medal despite a less than perfect last exchange between Griffith-Joyner and Ashford that required Ashford to run a sensational final leg to overtake Göhr.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-sports-reference.com-2)

At her  [last Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics")  in  [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), Ashford, aged 35, was eliminated in the 100 m semi-finals by 1/100th of a second; she went on to win her third straight Olympic 4 × 100 m relay gold, this time running 1st leg. She is one of only six women to have won four gold medals in track and field Olympic history.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-sports-reference.com-2)

Ashford came back from season ending injuries three times, to reach the top of the sport in the following year. In 1980 she injured her quad, and returned in 1981 with the sprint double at the World Cup and the number one world ranking in both sprints. After an injury in 1983, she became double Olympic Champion in 1984. In 1987 a hamstring pull prevented her from competing at the World Championships, then a season later added an Olympic Silver and third Gold medal to her collection.

On May 30, 1985 she gave birth to her daughter Raina Ashley Washington, and again came back for an excellent 1986, losing only once over both the 100 m and 200 m, and winning the 100 meter title at the Goodwill Games; earning another No. 1 ranking by  _Track & Field News_  over the shorter distance.

After parting ways with her coach  [Pat Connolly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Winslow "Pat Winslow")  (herself a 3-time Olympian) in 1985, Ashford was largely self-coached.

In 1997, Ashford was inducted into the  [National Track and Field Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Track_and_Field_Hall_of_Fame "National Track and Field Hall of Fame"),[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Ashford#cite_note-7)  where she is said to be "one of the greatest track and field runners ever." Ashford went to the  [University of California, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles "University of California, Los Angeles")  and  [Roseville High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roseville_High_School_(Roseville,_California) "Roseville High School (Roseville, California)"). She was inducted into the  [UCLA Athletics Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UCLA_Bruins#UCLA_Athletics_Hall_of_Fame "UCLA Bruins")  in 1990.

name: Yolanda
bio:
**Yolanda Gail Devers**  ([/ˈdiːvərz/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")  [_DEE-vərz_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-2)  born November 19, 1966) is an American retired  [track and field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field")  athlete. A two-time  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  champion in the 100 meters for the  [USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Olympic_Team "United States Olympic Team"), her 1996 win made her only the second woman (after  [Wyomia Tyus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wyomia_Tyus "Wyomia Tyus")) to successfully defend an Olympic 100m title. She won a third Olympic gold medal in the 4 × 100 m relay in 1996. She is also the  [1993 World champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1993 World Championships in Athletics")  in the 100m and a three-time  [World champion in the 100m hurdles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_World_Championships_in_Athletics_medalists_(women) "List of World Championships in Athletics medalists (women)"). In 2011, she was inducted into the  [National Track and Field Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Track_and_Field_Hall_of_Fame "National Track and Field Hall of Fame").

## Life and career

Devers was born in  [Seattle, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle,_Washington "Seattle, Washington"), and grew up near  [National City, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_City,_California "National City, California"), graduating from  [Sweetwater High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweetwater_High_School_(National_City,_California) "Sweetwater High School (National City, California)")  in 1984.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-usatf.org-1)  (Sweetwater's football and track stadium would later be named Gail Devers Stadium.) A young talent in the  [100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres "100 metres")  and  [100 m hurdles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres_hurdles "100 metres hurdles"), Devers was in training for the  [1988 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics"), started experiencing health problems, suffering from among others  [migraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migraine "Migraine")  and vision loss. She qualified for the Olympics 100 m hurdles, in which she was eliminated in the semi-finals, but her health continued to deteriorate even further.

In 1990, she was diagnosed with  [Graves' disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graves-Basedow_disease "Graves-Basedow disease")  and underwent  [radioactive iodine treatment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iodine-131 "Iodine-131")  followed by  [thyroid hormone replacement therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levothyroxine "Levothyroxine"). During her radiation treatment, Devers began to develop blistering and swelling of her feet. Eventually, the sprinter could barely walk and had to crawl and or be carried. A doctor considered amputating her feet. Amazingly, Devers recovered after the radiation treatment was discontinued, and she resumed training. At the 1991 World Championships, she won a  [silver medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_medal "Silver medal")  in the 100 m hurdles.

At the  [1992 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics"), Devers starred. She qualified for the final of the 100 m, which ended in an exciting finish, with five women finishing close (within 0.06 seconds). The  [photo finish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photo_finish "Photo finish")  showed Devers had narrowly beaten  [Jamaican](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica")  [Juliet Cuthbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juliet_Cuthbert "Juliet Cuthbert"). In the final of the 100 m hurdles, Devers' lead event, she seemed to be running towards a second  [gold medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_medal "Gold medal"), when she hit the final hurdle and stumbled over the finish line in fifth place, leaving  [Voula Patoulidou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voula_Patoulidou "Voula Patoulidou")  from  [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece")  as the upset winner.

In 1993, Devers won the 100 m World Championship title after - again - a photo finish win over  [Merlene Ottey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merlene_Ottey "Merlene Ottey")  in an apparent dead heat, and the 100 m hurdles title. She retained her hurdles title in 1995.

The 100 m final at the  [1996 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics")  was an almost exact repeat of the World Championships final three years before. Ottey and Devers again finished in the same time and did not know who had won the race. Again, both were awarded the same time of 10.94 seconds, but Devers was judged to have finished first and became the first woman to retain the Olympic 100 m title since  [Wyomia Tyus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wyomia_Tyus "Wyomia Tyus").  [Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shelly-Ann_Fraser-Pryce "Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce")  duplicated the feat in 2012. In the final of her favorite event, Devers again failed, as she finished fourth and outside of the medals. With the  [4 × 100 m relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_x_100_metres_relay "4 x 100 metres relay")  team, Devers won her third Olympic gold medal.

After these Olympics, Devers concentrated on the hurdles event, winning the World Championship again in 1999, but she had to forfeit for the semi-finals at the  [2000 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics").

Devers competed in the 100 m and 100 m hurdles at the  [2004 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")  in Athens, her fifth Olympic Games.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-3)

Devers left competition in 2005 to give birth to a child with her husband and returned in 2006.

On February 2, 2007, at the age of 40, Devers edged 2004 Olympic champion  [Joanna Hayes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joanna_Hayes "Joanna Hayes")  to win the  [60 m hurdles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60_metres_hurdles "60 metres hurdles")  event at the  [Millrose Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millrose_Games "Millrose Games")  in 7.86 seconds - the best time in the world that season and just 0.12 off the record she set in 2003. Furthermore, the time bettered the listed World Record for a 40-year-old by almost 7 tenths of a second.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-4)

During her career, Devers was notable for having exceptionally long, heavily decorated fingernails. One of the fastest starters in the world, Devers even had to alter her starting position to accommodate her long nails.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-5)  Her long nails came as the result of a contest her father devised to get her to stop biting her nails as a child.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-6)

Devers' brother was  [IFBB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Federation_of_BodyBuilding_%26_Fitness "International Federation of BodyBuilding & Fitness")  Professional  [Bodybuilder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodybuilder "Bodybuilder")  Parenthesis "PD" Devers.

## Achievements and recognition

In 2011, she was elected into the  [National Track and Field Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Track_and_Field_Hall_of_Fame "National Track and Field Hall of Fame"). The following year she was elected into the  [United States Olympic Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Olympic_Hall_of_Fame "United States Olympic Hall of Fame").[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-7)  In November 2012, Devers was announced as a 2013 recipient of the  [NCAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association")  [Silver Anniversary Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Anniversary_Awards_(NCAA) "Silver Anniversary Awards (NCAA)"), presented annually to six distinguished former college student-athletes on the 25th anniversary of the end of their college sports careers.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gail_Devers#cite_note-8)

name: Simon
bio:
**Simon St. Quentin Whitfield**  (born 16 May 1975 in  [Kingston, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingston,_Ontario "Kingston, Ontario")) is a retired  [Olympic triathlon champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Olympic_medalists_in_triathlon "List of Olympic medalists in triathlon")  from Canada. Whitfield won 10 consecutive Canadian Triathlon Championships titles and  [carried the Canadian national flag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_flag_bearers_for_Canada_at_the_Olympics "List of flag bearers for Canada at the Olympics")  during the  [2000 Summer Olympics closing ceremony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics_closing_ceremony "2000 Summer Olympics closing ceremony")  in Sydney, where he had won his gold medal, and the opening ceremony at the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics")  in London, making him one of few Canadian athletes to be honoured twice as Olympic flag bearer.


## Biography

As a young boy, Whitfield played  [soccer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer "Soccer"), until he began with  [triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon "Triathlon")  at age 11, honing his early competitive skills in the Canadian  _Kids of Steel_  program. By age 15, he was pursuing triathlon on a serious competitive basis. At present, Whitfield lives in  [Victoria, British Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria,_British_Columbia "Victoria, British Columbia")  and maintains his second residence at  [Salt Spring Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_Spring_Island "Salt Spring Island").

### Triathlon career

Whitfield won a gold medal in the triathlon at the  [2000 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics")  in  [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), Australia. He got up off the ground after he and 14 other riders crashed in the bike race portion of the event and worked his way back near the leaders. In the foot race, he cut down the field one at a time then put on a finishing kick to take the victory. His final time was 1:48:24.02, which until 2012 stood as the fastest Olympic triathlon.

In the  [2002 Commonwealth Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Commonwealth_Games "2002 Commonwealth Games")  in  [Manchester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchester "Manchester"), England he claimed gold again. He ended up in 11th place at the  [2004 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")  with a time of 1:53:15.81.

Whitfield was named to the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  team and won a silver medal while competing at his third consecutive games.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-Triathlon-2)  With a time of 1:48:58, he finished 5 seconds behind the German gold medalist.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-3)  Whitfield's accomplishment was made even more impressive considering he was a distant fourth behind the lead three runners heading into the final kilometre of the run before he burst forth into the lead with 200 metres remaining. Whitfield, exhausted by his effort to get back into the lead, was then passed by the eventual winner  [Jan Frodeno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Frodeno "Jan Frodeno")  of Germany at the end of the race.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-4)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Simon_Whitfield_with_flag.jpg/170px-Simon_Whitfield_with_flag.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Simon_Whitfield_with_flag.jpg)

Whitfield as flag bearer at the  [2012 Olympic Opening Ceremonies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Canada at the 2012 Summer Olympics")

Whitfield competed at the  [2012 London Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_London_Olympics "2012 London Olympics")  in Triathlon. After finishing 15th in the swim[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-5)  Whitfield was riding out of transition in his aero-bars when he was caught off balance going over a speed bump, falling off of his bike and breaking his collar bone, forcing him to drop out of the race.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-6)  Although disappointed, Whitfield remained composed and tactful, apologizing to a fellow athlete who was involved in the crash. Throughout the Olympics Whitfield continued to defend fellow triathlete and Olympic competitor  [Paula Findlay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paula_Findlay "Paula Findlay")  from the media when she came last in the women's triathlon in the London games.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-7)

Whitfield retired in 2013.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-8)

## Awards and honours

In 2017, Whitfeld was inducted into  [Canada's Sports Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%27s_Sports_Hall_of_Fame "Canada's Sports Hall of Fame").[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield#cite_note-9)

name: Robert
bio: **Robert Bartko** (born 23 December 1975 in [Potsdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam")) is a [road bicycle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_bicycle_racing "Road bicycle racing") and [track cyclist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_cyclist "Track cyclist") from [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany "Germany"), who was born in the former [East Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany"). He won two gold medals at the [2000 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics") in [Sydney, Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney,_Australia "Sydney, Australia"): in the individual and in the team pursuit. He competed in races for professional riders from 2001 to 2014.

name: Aleksandr
bio:
**Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Karelin**  ([_kah-RE-lin_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),  [Russian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"):  Александр Александрович Карелин,  IPA: [[ɐlʲɪkˈsandr ɐlʲɪkˈsandrəvʲɪtɕ kəˈrʲelʲɪn]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian "Help:IPA/Russian"); born 19 September 1967) is a retired  [Greco-Roman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling "Greco-Roman wrestling")  [wrestler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amateur_wrestling "Amateur wrestling")  for the  [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")  and  [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia "Russia"). Nicknamed the "Russian Bear",[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-2)  "Russian King Kong",[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-3)  "Alexander the Great" and "The Experiment", he is considered the greatest Greco-Roman wrestler of all time.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-4)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-5)  Karelin won gold medals at the 1988, 1992 and 1996  [Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  under a different flag each time (Soviet Union, Unified Team and Russia respectively), and a silver medal at the 2000 Olympic Games. His wrestling record is 887 wins and two losses.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-8)  Karelin was the national flag bearer at three consecutive Olympics: in 1988 for the Soviet Union, in 1992 for the  [Unified Team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_Team_at_the_Olympics "Unified Team at the Olympics"), and in 1996 for Russia.

## Wrestling career

Karelin was born as a 5.5 kilograms (12 lb) baby.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-karelinru2-9)  He began training in 1981, under Viktor Kuznetsov, who remained his coach through his entire career.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-iat-10)[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)  Before that he tried boxing, weightlifting, volleyball, basketball and skiing.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-fizvosp-11)  Karelin went undefeated for the first time from 1982 to 1987 and second time from 1987 to 2000. In 1985 he came to international competitions and won a junior world title.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)  He had his first loss (score 0–1) at the USSR championships in 1987, to the reigning Russian and European champion  [Igor Rostorotsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Rostorotsky "Igor Rostorotsky"); he defeated Rostorotsky at the next USSR championships while recovering from a flu and a recent concussion.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)

In the 1988 Olympic final Karelin was losing to  [Rangel Gerovski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangel_Gerovski "Rangel Gerovski"), but with 15 seconds left managed to execute his favorite  [Karelin Lift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suplex#Karelin_lift "Suplex")  and won.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)  At the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta, Karelin faced American  [Matt Ghaffari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Ghaffari "Matt Ghaffari")  for the gold medal. Karelin had come off a shoulder surgery and looked vulnerable against a strong Ghaffari, who was able to repel Karelin's efforts to lift and slam him, forcing Karelin to use all of his skill and experience to defend a 1–0 lead.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-autogenerated2000-12)

After going 13 years undefeated in international competition and six years without giving up a point, he lost 0–1 to  [Rulon Gardner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rulon_Gardner "Rulon Gardner")  of the  [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States "United States")  in the final of the  [Sydney Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics").[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-Miracle-13)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-14)[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-15)  Karelin retired from competitions in 2000.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-16)

### Wrestling style

Karelin was revered for his extraordinary strength and unprecedented success in international competition. He competed at the heaviest weight class of his day, 130 kg (286 lb). His conditioning and quickness combined with his dominance of the sport, led to him being known as "The Experiment". When asked why he thought he was called that, Karelin noted that others do not understand because "I train every day of my life as they have never trained a day in theirs".[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-Winner-17)  His coach was at first skeptical about a big but powerless boy, yet he accepted Karelin and motivated him for hard training, both in wrestling technique and physical strength. As a result, over the years Karelin progressed from 0 to 42  [pull-ups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pull-up_(exercise) "Pull-up (exercise)").[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-karelinru2-9)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-lift-18)

Karelin was famous for his reverse body lift, the Karelin Lift, where facing the opponent who was lying flat on the mat to keep from being thrown, Karelin hoisted his opponents into the air and slammed them violently to the mat. This devastatingly effective maneuver, when properly executed, awarded Karelin 5 points per throw, the maximum awarded in Greco-Roman wrestling. The throw had long been in use by lighter wrestlers but not by heavyweights – because of the immense strength required to raise, spin and hit the mat with a 560+ lbs combined weight of both athletes (280+ of which resist desperately to the performed manoeuver). Karelin's ability to perform this throw against elite opponents weighing as much as 130 kg amazed other participants and observers of the sport.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-lift-18)  In 889 fights, Karelin used the reverse body lift on circa 800 occasions, in some cases several times per round.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-19)

### Injuries

Like most top wrestlers, Karelin had a number of severe injuries through his career. He credits his fast recoveries to Valery Okhapkin, physician of the national wrestling team, and claims that Okhapkin extended his competition lifetime by several years.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)

At the age of 15 Karelin broke his leg while training; having learned about this accident his mother burned his wrestling uniform and forbade him to wrestle. Since then he broke his arms twice and ribs thirteen times. Around January 1988 he had a serious concussion, and doctors considered removing him from the 1988 Olympic team. Karelin won the 1993 World Championships despite breaking two ribs in the opening bout against  [Matt Ghaffari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Ghaffari "Matt Ghaffari"). At the 1996 European Championships in Budapest, he had torn the right chest muscle so badly that doctors predicted he would not be able to use his right hand for several months. Karelin won the Championships, but had to be urgently operated on in Budapest. He recovered within three months to compete at the 1996 Olympics.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Karelin#cite_note-pr-1)

name: Hicham
bio:
**Hicham El Guerrouj**  ([Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic "Arabic"):  هشام الݣروج,  _Hishāmu l-Karrūj_;  [Berber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berber_language "Berber language"): Hicam El Gerruj, ⵀⵉⵛⴰⵎ ⴻⵍ ⴳⴻⵔⵔⵓⵊ; born 14 September 1974) is a retired  [Moroccan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morocco "Morocco")  [middle-distance runner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle-distance_runner "Middle-distance runner"). El Guerrouj is the current  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_records_in_athletics "World records in athletics")  holder of the outdoor  [1500 meters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1500_metres_world_record_progression "1500 metres world record progression"),  [mile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_for_the_mile_run "World record progression for the mile run"), and  [2000 meters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_distance_track_event#2000_m "Middle distance track event")  events. He also held indoor world records for the mile and 1500 meters until 2019, and is the only man since  [Paavo Nurmi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi "Paavo Nurmi")  to earn a gold medal in both the  [1500 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1500_metres "1500 metres")  and  [5000 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5000_metres "5000 metres")  at the same  [Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games"). El Guerrouj holds 7 of the fastest 10 times ever run in the 1500 meters and in the mile.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-4)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-5)  He is considered by many to be the greatest middle-distance runner of all time.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-7)

In November 2014, he was inducted into the  [International Association of Athletics Federations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_of_Athletics_Federations "International Association of Athletics Federations")  (IAAF)  [Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_Hall_of_Fame "IAAF Hall of Fame").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-8)

## Early career

Born in  [Berkane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkane "Berkane"), Hicham El Guerrouj's first international triumph was at age 18, when he was third in the  [5000 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5000_metres "5000 metres")  of the  [1992 Junior World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_World_Junior_Championships_in_Athletics "1992 World Junior Championships in Athletics")  in Seoul, behind  [Haile Gebrselassie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haile_Gebrselassie "Haile Gebrselassie")  of Ethiopia and  [Ismael Kirui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ismael_Kirui "Ismael Kirui")  of  [Kenya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"). A year later, he was the #2 man on the Moroccan team at the  [World Junior Cross Country Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_IAAF_World_Cross_Country_Championships_%E2%80%93_Junior_men%27s_race "1993 IAAF World Cross Country Championships – Junior men's race").

In 1994, he was a member of the Moroccan team in the  [1994 IAAF World Road Relay Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1994_IAAF_World_Road_Relay_Championships&action=edit&redlink=1 "1994 IAAF World Road Relay Championships (page does not exist)"), which won the race in world record time.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-9)

El Guerrouj rose to international prominence in the mid-1990s with near-record times in the  [1500 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1500_metres "1500 metres")  and mile. At the age of 20 he finished second in the 1500 metres to then world record holder  [Noureddine Morceli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noureddine_Morceli "Noureddine Morceli")  at the  [1995 World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1995 World Championships in Athletics")  in Gothenburg. In 1996 after setting a new personal best in the 1500 metres of 3:29.59 in  [Stockholm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), he was considered one of the favourites for the  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  [gold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_medal "Gold medal").

## 1996 Atlanta Olympics – 1999 season

El Guerrouj competed in his first Olympic Games in 1996 at  [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics"). Running the 1500 metres final, as he was moving into position to challenge for the lead,[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-10)  he fell with 400 m to go and finished last in 12th place. He had been expected to challenge the world record holder and three-time  [World champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_champion "World champion"),  [Noureddine Morceli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noureddine_Morceli "Noureddine Morceli").[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-11)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-12)

One month later, at the Grand Prix final in Milan, El Guerrouj became the first runner to defeat Morceli over 1500 m in four years.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-13)  In the following years, El Guerrouj became the only middle distance runner to win four consecutive  [world titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "IAAF World Championships in Athletics")  in  [1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_World_Championships_in_Athletics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_1500_metres "1999 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 1500 metres"),[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-14)  [1999](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_World_Championships_in_Athletics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_1500_metres "1999 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 1500 metres"),[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-15)  [2001](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_World_Championships_in_Athletics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_1500_metres "2001 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 1500 metres"), and  [2003](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_1500_metres "2003 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 1500 metres").[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-16)

El Guerrouj set two  [world indoor records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_indoor_world_records_in_athletics "List of indoor world records in athletics")  at the start of the 1997 season, starting with a 1500 m record of 3:31.18 at the  [Sparkassen Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparkassen_Cup_(athletics) "Sparkassen Cup (athletics)"), beaten 22 years later, in 2019 by  [Samuel Tefera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Tefera "Samuel Tefera"). He also setting a new indoor best of 3:48.45 in the mile run at the  [Indoor Flanders meeting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indoor_Flanders_meeting "Indoor Flanders meeting")  a few weeks later. In 1998 in  [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome "Rome"), El Guerrouj broke Morceli's 1500 m world record (3:27.37) with a time of 3:26.00.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-17)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-18)[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-19)

In 1999, also in Rome, El Guerrouj broke the world record in the  [mile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mile_run "Mile run")  set by Noureddine Morceli in 1993, with a time of 3:43.13.  [Noah Ngeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Ngeny "Noah Ngeny")  of Kenya, who ran second, was also under the previous world record with a time of 3:43.40. This was the first time in over 40 years that two men had bettered the mile world record in the same race.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-20)

Later that season he set a new world record over  [2000 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_m "2000 m")  in  [Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin "Berlin")  at 4:44.79, bettering the previous mark set by Morceli by more than three seconds. He also ran the second fastest  [3000 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3000_m "3000 m")  ever in  [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels").

## 2000 Sydney Olympics – 2003 season

At the  [Sydney Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics"), El Guerrouj was favourite to take gold but finished second in the 1500 metres, behind  [Noah Ngeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Ngeny "Noah Ngeny"), a talented Kenyan runner at the peak of his career who had run as El Guerrouj's pacemaker when El Guerrouj ran his 1500m world record in Rome in 1998.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-23)

El Guerrouj successfully defended his 1500 m title in the  [2001](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2001 World Championships in Athletics")  and  [2003 World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Championships in Athletics")  and came close to breaking his own 1500 m record in  [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels")  in 2001 with a time of 3:26.12. He also won 3 consecutive  [IAAF Golden League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_Golden_League "IAAF Golden League")  prizes in 2001, 2002 and 2003. He was the only  [middle distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_distance_track_event "Middle distance track event")  athlete to produce the winning streak necessary to be entitled for a share of the jackpot of 50 kilograms (1,608 troy ounces) of  [gold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold "Gold")  (2000–2002) or US$1 million (1998–1999, 2003–present). He remains the only athlete to have won it three times in a row.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 2003, El Guerrouj set a personal best of 12:50.24 in the  [5000 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5000_metres "5000 metres"), which is the 16th fastest ever in the event. Later in the year, at the  [World Track & Field Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Championships in Athletics"), he finished a close second to Kenyan  [Eliud Kipchoge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliud_Kipchoge "Eliud Kipchoge")  in the 5000 metres, adding a silver to the gold he had previously won in the 1500 metres.

## 2004 Athens Olympics and retirement

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Carlos_ga...jpg/220px-Carlos_ga...jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carlos_ga...jpg)

El Guerrouj and Carlos García at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens

After a relatively poor start to the 2004 season that included slow times and an 8th-place finish in a 1500-metre race in Rome, El Guerrouj entered both the 1500 metres and the 5000 metres at the  [2004 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")  in  [Athens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athens "Athens"),  [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece").

Only 20 days before the Olympic final, 2000 Olympic bronze medalist  [Bernard Lagat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Lagat "Bernard Lagat")  ran the fastest 1500 m in 2004 (3:27.40), narrowly defeating El Guerrouj (3:27.64) at the  [Weltklasse Zürich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weltklasse_Z%C3%BCrich "Weltklasse Zürich")  meet on August 6. On August 24, in the final straight of the Olympic 1500m final, El Guerrouj beat Lagat by 0.12 seconds, winning the gold medal. In the finale, entering the home straight El Guerrouj led, only to be overtaken by Lagat- and then El Guerrouj re-took the lead a few strides from the line.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-24)

Four days later, El Guerrouj won the 5,000 m final with a time of 13:14.39, preventing  [Kenenisa Bekele](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenenisa_Bekele "Kenenisa Bekele")  from achieving the 5000 m/10000 m distance double, last achieved by Ethiopian  [Miruts Yifter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miruts_Yifter "Miruts Yifter")  in  [1980 Moscow Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics").[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-25)

El Guerrouj became the first man in 80 years to win both 1500m and 5000m titles in the same Olympics, previously achieved only by the "[Flying Finn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Finn "Flying Finn")"  [Paavo Nurmi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi "Paavo Nurmi")  in 1924.

Having fulfilled his sporting ambitions, El Guerrouj never competed internationally again and announced his retirement on May 22, 2006.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-26)[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-27)

## Awards and honors

His sporting career is marked by numerous recognitions such as the award to  [humanitarian effort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanitarianism "Humanitarianism")  from  [the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF "IAAF"), which he received in 1996. He is also a  [UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UNICEF_Goodwill_Ambassadors "List of UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors"). El Guerrouj was named  [IAAF World Athlete of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Athlete_of_the_Year "IAAF World Athlete of the Year")  in 2001, 2002 and 2003 after remaining unbeaten in more than 20 races, becoming the first man to win the award in consecutive years. He was also named best athlete of the year by the athletics journal  _[Track and Field News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_and_Field_News "Track and Field News")_  in 2002. In 2003, he was elected as a member of the  [IAAF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF "IAAF")  Athletes Committee.

On September 7, 2004, El Guerrouj was decorated with the "Cordon de Commandeur" by  [King Mohammed VI of Morocco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammed_VI_of_Morocco "Mohammed VI of Morocco"). In the same year, he was awarded the  [Prince of Asturias Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias_Awards "Prince of Asturias Awards").[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-28)

He was a member of the  [International Olympic Committee Athletes' Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_members_of_the_International_Olympic_Committee "List of members of the International Olympic Committee")  from 2004 to 2012.

Hicham El Guerrouj is today an Ambassador for  [Peace and Sport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_and_Sport "Peace and Sport"), a  [Monaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monaco "Monaco")-based international organization,[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj#cite_note-29)  as well as a member of its "Champions for Peace" club, a group of 54 famous elite athletes committed to serving peace in the world through sport.

name: Michael
bio:
**Michael Fred Phelps II**[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-TV_Guide-5)  (born June 30, 1985)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-biography.com-6)  is an American former competitive swimmer and the most successful and  [most decorated Olympian of all time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_medalists "List of multiple Olympic medalists"),[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-7)  with a total of 28 medals. Phelps also holds the all-time records for  [Olympic gold medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_gold_medalists#List_of_most_Olympic_gold_medals_over_career "List of multiple Olympic gold medalists")  (23),[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-sportscafe-8)  [Olympic gold medals in individual events](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_gold_medalists#List_of_most_career_gold_medals_in_individual_events "List of multiple Olympic gold medalists")  (13), and  [Olympic medals in individual events](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_medalists#List_of_most_career_medals_in_individual_events "List of multiple Olympic medalists")  (16).[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-9)  When he won eight gold medals at the  [2008 Beijing Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics"), Phelps broke fellow American swimmer  [Mark Spitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Spitz "Mark Spitz")'s 1972 record of seven  [first-place finishes at any single Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_gold_medalists_at_a_single_Games "List of multiple Olympic gold medalists at a single Games"). At the  [2004 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")  in  [Athens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athens "Athens"), Phelps had already tied the record of eight medals of any color at a single Games by winning six gold and two bronze medals. At the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics")  in  [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London"), Phelps won four gold and two silver medals, and at the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  in  [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), he won five gold medals and one silver. This made him the  [most successful](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lists_of_Olympic_medalists#Medalist_with_most_medals_by_Olympiad "Lists of Olympic medalists")  athlete of the Games for the fourth Olympics in a row.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-10)[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-11)

Phelps is the  [long course](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic-size_swimming_pool "Olympic-size swimming pool")  world record holder in the men's  [400-meter individual medley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_400_metres_individual_medley "World record progression 400 metres individual medley")  as well as the former long course world record holder in the  [200-meter freestyle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_200_metres_freestyle "World record progression 200 metres freestyle"),  [100-meter butterfly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_100_metres_butterfly "World record progression 100 metres butterfly"),  [200-meter butterfly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_200_metres_butterfly "World record progression 200 metres butterfly"), and  [200-meter individual medley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record_progression_200_metres_individual_medley "World record progression 200 metres individual medley"). He has won 82 medals in major international long course competitions, of which 65 were gold, 14 silver, and three bronze, spanning the Olympics, the  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FINA_World_Aquatics_Championships "FINA World Aquatics Championships"), and the  [Pan Pacific Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan_Pacific_Swimming_Championships "Pan Pacific Swimming Championships"). Phelps's international titles and record-breaking performances have earned him the  [World Swimmer of the Year Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_World_Swimmers_of_the_Year "Swimming World Swimmers of the Year")  eight times and  [American Swimmer of the Year Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_World_Swimmers_of_the_Year#American_Swimmer_of_the_Year "Swimming World Swimmers of the Year")  eleven times, as well as the  [FINA Swimmer of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_FINA_Athletes_of_the_Year#Swimming "List of FINA Athletes of the Year")  Award in 2012 and 2016. Phelps earned  _[Sports Illustrated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_  magazine's  [Sportsman of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sportsman_of_the_Year "Sportsman of the Year")  award due to his unprecedented Olympic success in the 2008 Games.

After the 2008 Summer Olympics, Phelps started the  [Michael Phelps Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps_Foundation "Michael Phelps Foundation"), which focuses on growing the sport of swimming and promoting healthier lifestyles. Phelps retired following the 2012 Olympics, but he made a comeback in April 2014.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-12)  At the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  in Rio de Janeiro,[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-13)  his fifth Olympics, he was selected by his team to be the  [flag bearer of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_flag_bearers_for_the_United_States_at_the_Olympics "List of flag bearers for the United States at the Olympics")  at the  [2016 Summer Olympics Parade of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics_Parade_of_Nations "2016 Summer Olympics Parade of Nations"). He announced his second retirement on August 12, 2016,[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-14)  having won more medals than 161 countries. He is often considered the greatest swimmer of all time.

## Physique

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Phelps_Santa_Clara_2009_-_start.jpg/220px-Phelps_Santa_Clara_2009_-_start.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Phelps_Santa_Clara_2009_-_start.jpg)

Phelps starting a race in 2009

Several physical attributes particularly suit Phelps to swimming: his long, thin torso offers low  [drag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drag_(physics) "Drag (physics)"); his arms span 6 feet 7 inches (201 cm)—disproportionate to his height of 6 feet 4 inches (193 cm)—and act as long, propulsive paddles; his relatively short legs lower drag, and perhaps add the speed enhancement of a  [hydrofoil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sailing_hydrofoil "Sailing hydrofoil"); his size-14 feet provide the effect of flippers; and his  [hypermobile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypermobility_(joints) "Hypermobility (joints)")  ankles can extend beyond the  [_pointe_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/En_pointe "En pointe")  of a ballet dancer, enabling him to whip his feet as if they were fins for maximum thrust through the water.[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-244)[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-245)

## Testing for performance-enhancing drugs

During the 2008 Olympics, Phelps was questioned by the press as to whether perhaps his feats were "too good to be true", a reference to unsupported rumors that Phelps might be taking  [performance-enhancing drugs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performance-enhancing_drug "Performance-enhancing drug").[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-246)[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-247)  In response, Phelps noted that he had signed up for Project Believe, a project by the  [United States Anti-Doping Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Anti-Doping_Agency "United States Anti-Doping Agency")  in which U.S. Olympians can volunteer to be tested in excess of the  [World Anti-Doping Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Anti-Doping_Agency "World Anti-Doping Agency")  guidelines.[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-248)  During the Games, Phelps passed all nine tests that were administered to him.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-249)[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-250)

## Training

Phelps has trained under  [Bob Bowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Bowman_(coach) "Bob Bowman (coach)")  since he was 11 years old.[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-251)  Bowman swam for  [Florida State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_State_University "Florida State University")  from 1983 to 1985.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-252)  Phelps has said Bowman reminded him of a  [drill sergeant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drill_instructor "Drill instructor")  because of his disciplined and regimented ways.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-253)  However, Phelps has said, "Training with Bob is the smartest thing I've ever done ... I'm not going to swim for anyone else."[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-254)  After the 2004 Summer Olympics, Bowman was hired as the head coach for the  [University of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Michigan "University of Michigan")  after  [Jon Urbanchek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Urbanchek "Jon Urbanchek")  retired. Phelps joined Bowman at Michigan to train and attended classes, but did not pursue a degree.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-255)[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-256)  Phelps served as a volunteer assistant coach at Michigan.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-257)  After the 2008 Summer Olympics, Bowman returned to Baltimore as CEO at the  [North Baltimore Aquatic Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Baltimore_Aquatic_Club "North Baltimore Aquatic Club"). Phelps also returned to Baltimore with Bowman.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-258)  When Bowman was hired as the men's and women's swimming coach at  [Arizona State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_State_University "Arizona State University")  in 2015, Phelps moved to Arizona to continue training under Bowman.[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-259)  There is a popular myth that Phelps ate 12,000 calories every day, but Phelps has stated it’s been exaggerated and that he didn’t eat so much even in his growing days.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-eisenband-260)[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-jennings-261)

## Personal life

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Michael_Phelps_%26_Nicole_Johnson_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/220px-Michael_Phelps_%26_Nicole_Johnson_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Michael_Phelps_%26_Nicole_Johnson_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)

Phelps with his wife, Nicole Johnson

Bob Bowman described Phelps as "a solitary man"[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-Phelps_life-262)  with a "rigid focus"[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-voyage-15)  at the pool prior to a race, but afterward "a man incredibly invested in the success of the people he cares about".[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-voyage-15)  He states that "he's unbelievably kind-hearted",[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-Phelps_life-262)  recounting Phelps's interaction with young children after practices.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-voyage-15)

Phelps is married to former  [Miss California USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miss_California_USA "Miss California USA")  [Nicole Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicole_Johnson_(Miss_California_USA) "Nicole Johnson (Miss California USA)"). They secretly married on June 13, 2016, and the marriage was not publicly reported until four months later.[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-263)  They met in 2007 at the  [ESPYs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPY_Award "ESPY Award"), broke up in 2012, reconciled, and got engaged in February 2015.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-engaged-264)[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-265)  They have three sons, Boomer Robert Phelps, born on May 5, 2016,[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-266)  Beckett Richard Phelps, born on February 12, 2018,[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-267)  and Maverick Nicolas Phelps, born on September 9, 2019.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-268)  The family lives in  [Paradise Valley, Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradise_Valley,_Arizona "Paradise Valley, Arizona"), an affluent town adjoined to Phoenix, where Phelps volunteers alongside Bowman as an assistant coach for the  [Arizona State Sun Devils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_State_Sun_Devils "Arizona State Sun Devils")  swim team.[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-269)

As a teenager, Phelps idolized Australian swimmer  [Ian Thorpe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ian_Thorpe "Ian Thorpe")  and modeled his public image after Thorpe.[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-270)  Thorpe initially said that it would be highly unlikely for Phelps to win eight gold medals at the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in Beijing.[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-271)  Phelps used the remarks as motivation and taped the words to his locker during the Games.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-272)  Thorpe was in the stands for the  [4×100-meter medley relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_medley_relay "Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metre medley relay"), where Phelps was swimming for his eighth Olympic gold medal. When Phelps and his teammates captured the gold, Thorpe gave a congratulatory kiss to Phelps's mother, then gave a handshake and a hug to congratulate Phelps. Afterwards, Thorpe said "I'm really proud of him not just because he won eight golds. Rather, it's how much he has grown up and matured into a great human being. Never in my life have I been so happy to have been proved wrong."[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-Phelps,_No_Limits,_p._218-146)[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-273)

Phelps has also cited  [Michael Jordan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan")  as a sporting idol of his, and stated that "he changed the sport of basketball".[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-274)

In January 2018, Phelps revealed that he has struggled both with  [ADHD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attention_deficit_hyperactivity_disorder "Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder")  and  [depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder "Major depressive disorder"), having contemplated suicide after the 2012 Olympics.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-275)[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-276)

## Legal issues

At age 19 in November 2004, Phelps was arrested for  [driving under the influence of alcohol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driving_under_the_influence_of_alcohol "Driving under the influence of alcohol")  in  [Salisbury, Maryland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salisbury,_Maryland "Salisbury, Maryland").[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-277)  He pleaded guilty to  [driving while impaired](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driving_while_impaired "Driving while impaired")  and was sentenced to serve 18 months of  [probation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probation "Probation"), fined $250, ordered to speak to high school students about drinking and driving, and to attend a  [Mothers Against Drunk Driving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mothers_Against_Drunk_Driving "Mothers Against Drunk Driving")  (MADD) meeting.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-278)  When Phelps was later asked about the incident by  [Matt Lauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Lauer "Matt Lauer")  on the  [_Today Show_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Today_(NBC_program) "Today (NBC program)"), he said that he had "let a lot of people in the country down."[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-voyage-15)

In February 2009, a photograph of Phelps using a  [bong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bong "Bong")  went viral; this resulted in the loss of the  [Kellogg Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kellogg_Company "Kellogg Company")  as a sponsor, as well as a three-month suspension by  [USA Swimming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Swimming "USA Swimming"). Phelps admitted that the photo, which was taken at a party at the  [University of South Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_South_Carolina "University of South Carolina"), was authentic. He publicly apologized, saying his behavior was "inappropriate".[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-279)

In September 2014, Phelps was arrested again, this time on charges of driving under the influence of alcohol and speeding in  [Baltimore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore"), Maryland.[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-280)  As a result, USA Swimming suspended him from all competitions for six months, and stated he would not be chosen to represent the United States at the  [2015 World Aquatics Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_World_Aquatics_Championships "2015 World Aquatics Championships")  in August.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-281)  With Phelps off the team, the United States failed to qualify for the finals of the 4 × 100 m freestyle relay.[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Phelps#cite_note-nbcolympics.com-219)

name: Noriaki
bio:
**Noriaki Kasai** (葛西 紀明,  _Kasai Noriaki_, born 6 June 1972)  is a Japanese  [ski jumper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumper "Ski jumper"). His career achievements include a gold medal at the  [1992 Ski Flying World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Ski_Flying_World_Championships_1992 "FIS Ski Flying World Championships 1992"), winning the  [1999 Nordic Tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_Tournament_1999 "Nordic Tournament 1999"), individual silver medal at the  [2014 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics"), and two individual bronze medals at the  [2003 Ski Jumping World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_2003 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2003").

During his career, Kasai broke numerous ski jumping records. In 2016, Kasai was honoured with two  [Guinness World Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records")  certificates for the most individual  [World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "FIS Ski Jumping World Cup")  starts, not only in ski jumping, but in all World Cup disciplines organized by the  [International Ski Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Ski_Federation "International Ski Federation"). Kasai has been competing for 31 seasons between  [1988–89](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988%E2%80%9389_FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "1988–89 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup")  and  [2019–20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "2019–20 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup"), and consecutively since  [1995–96](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "1995–96 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup").

## Career

### 1988: World Cup debut

Kasai made his  [World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "FIS Ski Jumping World Cup")  debut on  [17 December 1988](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988%E2%80%9389_FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "1988–89 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup")  in  [Sapporo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Okurayama_Ski_Jump_Stadium "Okurayama Ski Jump Stadium"), Japan, at the age of 16, reaching 31st place. A year later he performed in his first  [Nordic World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships")  in  [Lahti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lahti "Lahti"), Finland.

### 1992: World champion

He won his first and to date only major championship at the  [FIS Ski Flying World Championships 1992](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Ski_Flying_World_Championships_1992 "FIS Ski Flying World Championships 1992")  in  [Harrachov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8Cer%C5%A5%C3%A1k "Čerťák"), Czechoslovakia. He won after a second day of competition which was cancelled after strong winds and a crash of  [Christof Duffner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christof_Duffner "Christof Duffner"). At that time he was among the world's top jumpers, known for his extraordinary style, holding his body almost flat between his skis.

### 1994: Olympic team medal

In 1994, he was a member of the Japanese national team that won a silver medal in the team large hill and finished fifth in the individual large hill at the  [Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics "1994 Winter Olympics")  in  [Lillehammer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lysg%C3%A5rdsbakken "Lysgårdsbakken"). After breaking his shoulder he missed the entire  [1994/95](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_FIS_Ski_Jumping_World_Cup "1994–95 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup")  season.

### 1999: Nordic Tournament

In 1999, Kasai won the ski jumping competition at the  [Holmenkollen Ski Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holmenkollen_Ski_Festival "Holmenkollen Ski Festival")  and  [Nordic Tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_Tournament_1999 "Nordic Tournament 1999")  overall title. He collected a total of seven medals at the  [Nordic World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships"), including two silver (team large hill in 1999 and 2003) and five bronze medals (individual normal hill and individual large hill in 2003, team large hill in 2007 and 2009, and mixed team normal hill in 2015). At the  [2010 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics "2010 Winter Olympics")  in  [Vancouver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), he finished eighth on the  [large hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Large_hill_individual "Ski jumping at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Large hill individual")  and 17th on the  [normal hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Normal_hill_individual "Ski jumping at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Normal hill individual").

### 2014: Oldest Olympic medalist

At the  [2014 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics")  in  [Sochi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sochi "Sochi")  he competed in a record seventh Olympics and took the silver medal in the  [large hill individual](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_2014_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_large_hill_individual "Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill individual")  and the bronze in  [team large hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_2014_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_large_hill_team "Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill team"), becoming the oldest ski jumper ever to take a medal at the winter Olympics.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai#cite_note-oldestolympics-1)

On 29 November 2014 Kasai became the oldest World Cup winner when he shared the victory with  [Simon Ammann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Ammann "Simon Ammann")  in  [Ruka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rukatunturi "Rukatunturi"), Finland.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai#cite_note-oldestwinnerwc-2)
