On 22 February 2015 Kasai won the bronze medal at the  [FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_2015 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2015")  in  [mixed team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_2015_%E2%80%93_Mixed_team_normal_hill "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2015 – Mixed team normal hill")  event and became the oldest medalist at the  [Nordic World Ski Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships"). He performed for a record twelfth time in the competition.

### 2016: 500th World Cup start

On 4 March 2016 he was on a World Cup podium in  [Wisła](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wis%C5%82a "Wisła")  at the age of 43 years and 272 days, which is a record for the oldest contestant to mount the podium in ski jumping history.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai#cite_note-3)  On 17 March 2016 in Planica, he reached his 500th individual start in the World Cup.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai#cite_note-4)

### 2018 Olympics
Kasai finished 21st in the  [normal hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_normal_hill_individual "Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual")  at the  [2018 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics "2018 Winter Olympics").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai#cite_note-TNY199-5)

name: Lidia
bio:
**Lidia Valentín Pérez**  (born 10 February 1985) is a Spanish  [weightlifter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting "Olympic weightlifting"), Olympic Champion, 2 time World Champion and 4 time European Champion competing in the 75 kg category until 2018 and 81 kg starting in 2018 after the  [International Weightlifting Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Weightlifting_Federation "International Weightlifting Federation")  reorganized the categories.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-1)  Lidia has won three  [Olympic Medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_medal "Olympic medal")  ([Silver in 2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics"),  [Gold in 2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  and  [Bronze in 2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics "Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics")), two World Weightlifting Championships ([2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_World_Weightlifting_Championships "2017 World Weightlifting Championships")  and  [2018](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_World_Weightlifting_Championships "2018 World Weightlifting Championships")), as well as four  [European Weightlifting Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_European_Weightlifting_Championships_medalists "List of European Weightlifting Championships medalists").[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-iwf.net-2)[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-3)[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-4)

## Contents

-   [1Career](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#Career)
    -   [1.1Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#Olympics)
-   [2Major results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#Major_results)
-   [3See also](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#See_also)
-   [4References](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#References)
-   [5External links](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#External_links)

## Career[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro "Edit section: Career")]

At the  [2007 World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_World_Weightlifting_Championships_-_Women%27s_75_kg "2007 World Weightlifting Championships - Women's 75 kg"), she ranked sixth in the 75 kg category with a total of 240 kg.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-IAT-5)

At the  [2013 World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_World_Weightlifting_Championships "2013 World Weightlifting Championships"), she won bronze in the snatch and placed fourth in the total, being promoted to silver and bronze respectively when  [Olga Zubova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Zubova "Olga Zubova")  was disqualified for failing a doping test.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-7)  In 2017, Lidia won the  [World Weightlifting Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_World_Weightlifting_Championships "2017 World Weightlifting Championships")  held in  [Anaheim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anaheim,_California "Anaheim, California"), United States.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-iwf.net-2)

At the  [European Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Weightlifting_Championships "European Weightlifting Championships"), she won four gold medals for the total in  [2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2014 European Weightlifting Championships"),  [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2015 European Weightlifting Championships"),  [2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2017 European Weightlifting Championships")  and  [2018](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2018 European Weightlifting Championships")  three silver medals (in  [2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2008 European Weightlifting Championships"),  [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2012 European Weightlifting Championships")  and  [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2013 European Weightlifting Championships")) and three bronze medals (in  [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2007 European Weightlifting Championships"),  [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2009 European Weightlifting Championships")  and  [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_European_Weightlifting_Championships "2011 European Weightlifting Championships")), with three gold and four silver medals in the  [snatch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snatch_(weightlifting) "Snatch (weightlifting)"), and two gold, one silver and five bronze medals in the  [clean and jerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clean_and_jerk "Clean and jerk").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-IAT-5)

### Olympics[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro "Edit section: Olympics")]

In 2008, Valentín competed at the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics")  in the 75 kg category finishing in fifth place at the time of competition with a 250 kg total.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-r1-8)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-9)  In 2016 retest of samples from the 75 kg category at the 2008 Olympics returned positive results for the original gold medalist  [Cao Lei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cao_Lei "Cao Lei")[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-10)  and bronze medalist  [Nadezhda Evstyukhina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadezhda_Evstyukhina "Nadezhda Evstyukhina"),[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-11)  their results were disqualified and Valentín was awarded the silver medal.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-13)

In 2012, Valentín competed at the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  in the 75 kg category again. This time she finished in fourth place with a 265 kg total, behind the 8 new Olympic Records set by  [Svetlana Podobedova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svetlana_Podobedova "Svetlana Podobedova")  and  [Natalia Zabolotnaya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natalia_Zabolotnaya "Natalia Zabolotnaya"). In 2016 during retests, all three original medalists had returned positive results thus disqualifying their medals and Olympic Records.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-14)[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-15)[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-16)  This made Valentín the Olympic Champion by default and in March 2019 she was awarded her gold medal.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-17)

In 2016, while waiting for confirmation of these medals, Valentín competed in the  [2016 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_75_kg "Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 75 kg"), where she lifted a total of 257 kg and won the bronze medal. It was, at the time, Spain's first medal ever in weightlifting (retrospectively third).[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-18)[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidia_Valent%C3%ADn#cite_note-19)

name: Chase
bio:
**Chase Tyler Kalisz**  (born March 7, 1994) is an American competition  [swimmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_(sport) "Swimming (sport)")  who specializes in the  [individual medley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medley_swimming "Medley swimming"), but also competes in the  [breaststroke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breaststroke "Breaststroke")  and  [butterfly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butterfly_stroke "Butterfly stroke")  events.

At the  [2013 World Aquatics Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_World_Aquatics_Championships "2013 World Aquatics Championships")  in Barcelona, Kalisz won silver in the  [400-meter individual medley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2013_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_400_metre_individual_medley "Swimming at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships – Men's 400 metre individual medley"), finishing with a time of 4:09.22, which was half a second behind gold medal winner  [Daiya Seto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daiya_Seto "Daiya Seto")  of Japan.

Kalisz attends the  [University of Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Georgia "University of Georgia"), where he competed for the  [Georgia Bulldogs swimming and diving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_Bulldogs_swimming_and_diving "Georgia Bulldogs swimming and diving")  team.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chase_Kalisz#cite_note-1)  Kalisz won the 400-yard individual medley at the 2013 NCAA Championships in Indianapolis as a freshman, finishing with a time of 3:38.05. The following year, Kalisz successfully defended his title and broke the  [American record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_records_in_swimming "List of United States records in swimming")  in the 400-yard individual medley previously held by  [Tyler Clary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyler_Clary "Tyler Clary")  with a time of 3:34.50.

At the 2016 United States Olympic Trials, Kalisz qualified for the 2016 Olympic Team for the 400 Meter Individual Medley with a time of 4:09.54. Kalisz won silver in the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics").

His senior year at Georgia, Kalisz won the 400 IM once again, breaking his own American Record with a time of 3:33.41.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chase_Kalisz#cite_note-2)

At the 2017 Phillips 66 National Championships in Indianapolis, Kalisz won both the 200 and 400 Meter Individual Medleys, earning himself a spot on the 2017 World Championship Team in those events. He also finished 3rd in the 200 Meter Butterfly, barely missing qualifying for the national team in that event.

At the 2017 FINA World Championships, Kalisz won gold in both of his events, setting a new Championship Record in the 400 IM in a time of 4:05.90, beating the previous record held by Michael Phelps set a decade before in Melbourne.

name: Andy
bio:
**Sir Andrew Barron Murray**  [OBE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order of the British Empire")  (born 15 May 1987) is a British professional  [tennis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis "Tennis")  player from Scotland. Murray represents  [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  in his sporting activities and is a three-time  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  tournament winner, two-time  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympics "Olympics")  champion,  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  champion, winner of the  [2016 ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles"), and former  [world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players").

Murray defeated  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  in the  [2012 US Open final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 US Open – Men's Singles"), becoming the first British player since 1977, and the first British man since 1936, to win a  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  singles tournament. Murray is also the first British man to win multiple  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  singles titles since  [Fred Perry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Perry "Fred Perry")  in 1936,[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Newbery-12)  winning the tournament in  [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles")  and  [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles").

Murray is the men's singles  [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles")  and  [2016 Olympic gold medallist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"), making him the only tennis player, male or female, to have won two Olympic singles titles. He featured in  [Great Britain's Davis Cup-winning team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  in  [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2015 Davis Cup World Group"), going 11–0 in his matches (8 singles and 3 doubles) as they secured their first  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  title since  [1936](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_Davis_Cup "1936 Davis Cup").[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Newbery-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-13)


## Early and personal life

Andy Murray was born in Glasgow, Scotland, the son of  [Judy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judy_Murray "Judy Murray")  (née Erskine) and William Murray.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-birth1-4)  His maternal grandfather,  [Roy Erskine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Erskine "Roy Erskine"), was a professional  [footballer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football "Association football")  in the late 1950s.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-14)  Murray is a supporter of  [Hibernian Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hibernian_F.C. "Hibernian F.C."), one of the teams his grandfather represented,[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-15)  and  [Arsenal Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.").[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-16)

Murray began playing tennis at the age of three when his mother Judy took him to play on the local courts.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-17)  He played in his first competitive tournament at age five and by the time he was eight he was competing with adults in the Central District Tennis League.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-18)  Murray's elder brother,  [Jamie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Murray "Jamie Murray"), is also a professional tennis player, playing on the doubles circuit, and became a multiple Grand Slam winner in the discipline (both men's and mixed).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-19)[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-20)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-23)

Murray grew up in  [Dunblane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane "Dunblane")  and attended  [Dunblane Primary School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_Primary_School "Dunblane Primary School"). He and his brother were present during the 1996  [Dunblane school massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_school_massacre "Dunblane school massacre"),[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Faultless_young_Scot-24)  when Thomas Hamilton killed 16 children and a teacher before shooting himself; Murray took cover in a classroom.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-25)  Murray says he was too young to understand what was happening and is reluctant to talk about it in interviews, but in his autobiography  _Hitting Back_  he states that he attended a youth group run by Hamilton and his mother gave Hamilton lifts in her car.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-26)  Murray later attended  [Dunblane High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_High_School "Dunblane High School").[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-times_interview-27)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)

Murray's parents split up when he was 10, with the boys living with their father while being mentored in tennis by their mother.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_facts-29)  He believes the impact this had on him could be the reason behind his competitive spirit.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-30)  At 15, he was asked to train with  [Rangers Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangers_F.C. "Rangers F.C.")  at their School of Excellence, but declined, opting to focus on his tennis career instead.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-31)  He then decided to move to Barcelona, Spain. There he studied at the  [Schiller International School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schiller_International_School "Schiller International School")  and trained on the clay courts of the Sánchez-Casal Academy, coached by Pato Alvarez.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Coaches-32)  Murray described this time as "a big sacrifice".[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)  His parents had to find £40,000 to pay for his 18-month stay there.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_facts-29)  In Spain, he trained with  [Emilio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilio_S%C3%A1nchez "Emilio Sánchez"), former world No. 1 doubles player.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)

Murray was born with a bipartite  [patella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patella "Patella"), where the kneecap remains as two separate bones instead of fusing together in early childhood, but was not diagnosed until the age of 16. He has been seen holding his knee due to the pain caused by the condition and has pulled out of events because of it.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-33)

In February 2013, Murray bought  [Cromlix House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cromlix_House "Cromlix House")  hotel near Dunblane, where his brother Jamie had celebrated his wedding in 2010[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-34)  but which had since ceased trading, for £1.8 million; the venue re-opened as a 15-room five-star hotel in April 2014.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-35)  Later that month Murray was awarded freedom of Stirling and received an Honorary Doctorate from the  [University of Stirling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Stirling "University of Stirling")  in recognition of his services to tennis.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-36)

Murray began dating Kim Sears, daughter of player-turned-coach  [Nigel Sears](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigel_Sears "Nigel Sears"), in 2005.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-37)[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcengage-38)  Their engagement was announced in November 2014,[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcengage-38)  and they married on 11 April 2015 at  [Dunblane Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_Cathedral "Dunblane Cathedral")  in his home town,[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcwedding-39)  with the reception at his Cromlix House hotel. The couple live in  [Oxshott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxshott "Oxshott"),  [Surrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey "Surrey")[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Andy_Murray_vows_he_will_never_be_a_%E2%80%98tax_exile%E2%80%99-1)  with their son and two daughters.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-40)[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-41)[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-42)  He identifies himself as a  [feminist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist "Feminist"), and has been repeatedly vocal in his support for women players and coaches.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-43)[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_Feminist-44)

Murray has invested in up to 30 UK businesses using  [Seedrs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seedrs "Seedrs"), a crowdfunding platform.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-45)

## Career

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png/220px-Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png)

Andy Murray Singles Ranking History Chart

### Junior tennis

[Leon Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Smith_(tennis_coach) "Leon Smith (tennis coach)"), Murray's tennis coach from 11 to 17,[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Coaches-32)  described Murray as "unbelievably competitive", while Murray attributes his abilities to the motivation gained from losing to his older brother Jamie. In 1999, at the age of 12, Murray won his age group at the  [Orange Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junior_Orange_Bowl_(tennis) "Junior Orange Bowl (tennis)"), a prestigious event for junior players.[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-46)  He won it again at the age of 14, and is one of only nine tennis players to win the Junior Orange Bowl championship twice in its 70-year history, alongside the likes of  [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors"),  [Jennifer Capriati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jennifer_Capriati "Jennifer Capriati"),  [Monica Seles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monica_Seles "Monica Seles"), and  [Yishai Oliel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yishai_Oliel "Yishai Oliel").[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-ynetnews.com-47)

In July 2003, Murray started out on the  [Challenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Challenger_Tour "ATP Challenger Tour")  and  [Futures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_Men%27s_Circuit "ITF Men's Circuit")  circuit. In his first tournament, he reached the  [quarter-finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarter-finals "Quarter-finals")  of the  [Manchester Challenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchester_Open "Manchester Open").[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-48)  In September, Murray won his first senior title by taking the  [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow")  Futures event.[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-49)  He also reached the semi-finals of the  [Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh")  Futures event.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-50)

For the first six months of 2004, Murray had a knee injury and couldn't play.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Injury_2004-2005-51)

In July 2004, Murray played a Challenger event in  [Nottingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nottingham "Nottingham"), where he lost to future  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  finalist  [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga")  in the second round.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-52)  Murray then went on to win Futures events in  [Xàtiva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X%C3%A0tiva "Xàtiva")[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-53)  and  [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome "Rome").[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-54)

In September 2004, he won the  [Junior US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis) "2004 US Open (tennis)")  and was selected for the  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  [World Group play-off match against Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Davis_Cup_World_Group_Play-offs "2004 Davis Cup World Group Play-offs")  later that month;[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-55)  however, he was not selected to play. Later that year, he won  [BBC Young Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Young_Personality "BBC Sports Personality of the Year Young Personality").[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-56)

As a junior, Murray reached as high as No. 6 in the world in 2003 (and No. 8 in doubles). In the 2004-instated combined rankings, he reached No. 2 in the world.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-57)

Junior Slam results:  Australian Open: -  
French Open: SF ([2005](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2005 French Open – Boys' Singles"))  
Wimbledon: 3R ([2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2004 Wimbledon Championships – Boys' Singles"))  
US Open:  **W**  ([2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2004 US Open – Boys' Singles"))

### 2005: Turning professional

Murray began 2005 ranked No. 407,[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-58)  but when he was in South America in January, he hurt his back and had to take three months off.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Injury_2004-2005-51)

In March, he became the youngest Briton to play in the  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup").[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Youngest-59)  Murray turned professional in April and was given a  [wild card](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wild_card_(sports)#Professional_tennis "Wild card (sports)")  entry to a clay-court tournament in Barcelona, the  [Open SEAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_SEAT "Open SEAT"), where he lost in three sets to  [Jan Hernych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Hernych "Jan Hernych").[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-60)  In April, Murray parted acrimoniously from his coach Pato Alvarez, complaining about his negative attitude.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Mark_Petchey-61)  Murray then reached the semi-finals of the boys' French Open, where he lost in straight sets to  [Marin Čilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87 "Marin Čilić").[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-62)

[Mark Petchey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Petchey "Mark Petchey")  agreed to coach Murray for four weeks until the end of Wimbledon, but it metamorphosed into a full-time position.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Mark_Petchey-61)  Given a wild card to  [Queen's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships"),[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-63)  Murray progressed past  [Santiago Ventura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Ventura_Bertomeu "Santiago Ventura Bertomeu")  in straight sets for his first ATP match win.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-64)  Following a second-round win against  [Taylor Dent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Dent "Taylor Dent"),[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-65)  he played former Australian Open champion  [Thomas Johansson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Johansson "Thomas Johansson")  in the third round, losing in three sets after cramping and twisting his ankle.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-66)[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-67)  Following his performance at Queen's, Murray received a wild card for  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"). Ranked No. 312, Murray became the first Scot in the  [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era")  to reach the third round of the men's singles tournament at Wimbledon.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-68)  In the third round, Murray lost to 2002 Wimbledon finalist  [David Nalbandian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Nalbandian "David Nalbandian")  due to cramping and fatigue, having led two sets to love.[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-69)

Following Wimbledon, Murray won Challenger events on the hard courts of  [Aptos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aptos "Aptos")  and  [Binghamton, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binghamton,_New_York "Binghamton, New York"). He then experienced his first  [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP World Tour Masters 1000")  event at  [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters"), where he beat  [Taylor Dent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Dent "Taylor Dent"), before losing in three sets to then-No. 4,  [Marat Safin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marat_Safin "Marat Safin"). With a wild card entry, Murray played  [Andrei Pavel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrei_Pavel "Andrei Pavel")  in the opening round of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), where he recovered from down two sets to one to win his first five-set match.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-70)  However, he lost in the second round to  [Arnaud Clément](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnaud_Cl%C3%A9ment "Arnaud Clément")  in another five-set contest.[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-71)  Murray was again selected for the Davis Cup match against Switzerland. He was picked for the opening singles rubbers, losing in straight sets to  [Stanislas Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislas_Wawrinka "Stanislas Wawrinka").[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-72)  Murray made his first ATP final at the  [Thailand Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PTT_Thailand_Open_(ATP) "PTT Thailand Open (ATP)")  where he faced No. 1  [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer"). Murray lost in straight sets.[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-73)

Murray beat  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")  in their first meeting, at the  [Basel Swiss Indoors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Davidoff_Swiss_Indoors_%E2%80%93_Singles#Top_Half "2005 Davidoff Swiss Indoors – Singles")  in the first round, and eventually reached the quarter-finals.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-74)

In November, Murray captained Scotland at the inaugural  [Aberdeen Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberdeen_Cup "Aberdeen Cup")  against England led by  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski").[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-75)  This was an exhibition tournament and the only event where Murray played Rusedski, they never met on the Tour. Rusedski beat Murray in the first match, but Murray won the second. This was also the first time that Andy and his brother  [Jamie Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Murray "Jamie Murray")  played doubles as seniors.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-BBC_format-76)  Scotland defeated England 4½ – 2½.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-77)  He completed the year ranked No. 64 and was named the 2005  [BBC Scotland Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Scotland_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Scotland Sports Personality of the Year").[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-78)

### 2006: First ATP Title and British No. 1
The 2006 season saw Murray compete on the full circuit for the first time and split with his coach Mark Petchey[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-79)  and team up with  [Brad Gilbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Gilbert "Brad Gilbert").[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-80)

On 27 February, Murray became the British No. 1, ending  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")'s seven-year run. Murray was now world No. 42,  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski")  No. 43, and Tim Henman No. 49.[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-81)  Rusedski regained his British No. 1 status on 15 May[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-82)  for eight weeks.[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-83)

Murray suffered a straight sets defeat at the Australian Open, to Argentine  [Juan Ignacio Chela](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Ignacio_Chela "Juan Ignacio Chela")  in the first round[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-84)  and to  [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils")  at the French Open, in five sets.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-85)  Murray did reach the fourth round for the first time at both Wimbledon (beating 3rd seed Andy Roddick in the 3rd round) and the US Open.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-86)[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-87)

Murray played in Davis Cup ties against  [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"),  [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel "Israel")  and  [Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine"). Murray missed the opening singles matches before losing the doubles as Britain lost their tie against Serbia.[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-88)  During the tie with Israel, Murray won his rubber and lost the doubles before pulling out with a neck injury before the reverse singles, as Britain lost the tie.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-89)[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-90)[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-91)  Against Ukraine, Murray won both his singles rubbers, but lost the doubles, as Britain won the tie.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-92)[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-93)[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-94)

At the Masters, Murray lost in the first round in Miami,[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-95)  Monte Carlo and Rome.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-96)[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-97)  Murray went out of the tournaments in Indian Wells and Hamburg in the second round.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-98)[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-99)  Murray reached his first Masters semi-final in  [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto "Toronto")  at the  [Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Cup_(tennis) "Rogers Cup (tennis)"), losing to  [Richard Gasquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Gasquet "Richard Gasquet").[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-100)

At  [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters "Western & Southern Financial Group Masters"), Murray became only one of two players, alongside  [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal"), to defeat Roger Federer in 2006, breaking the Swiss star's 55 match winning streak on hard courts.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-101)  He lost two rounds later to Andy Roddick, but broke into the top 20 for the first time.[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-102)[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-103)  In the final two Masters events in Madrid and Paris, Murray exited both tournaments at the last-16 stage ending his season, with losses to  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  and  [Dominik Hrbatý](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominik_Hrbat%C3%BD "Dominik Hrbatý").[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-104)[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-105)  When the tour reached  [San Jose, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California"); Murray defeated a top ten player for the first time,  [Andy Roddick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Roddick "Andy Roddick").[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-106)  Murray went on to claim the  [SAP Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAP_Open "SAP Open")  title defeating No. 11  [Lleyton Hewitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt "Lleyton Hewitt").[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-107)  Murray was a finalist at the  [Legg Mason Tennis Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legg_Mason_Tennis_Classic "Legg Mason Tennis Classic").[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-108)  Playing doubles with his brother in Bangkok the pair reached the final.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-109)  After the French Open, where Murray was injured again, he revealed that his bones hadn't fully grown, causing him to suffer from cramps and back problems.[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-110)

In November, the  [Aberdeen Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberdeen_Cup "Aberdeen Cup")  was held for the second time, with Murray leading team Scotland and  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski")  captaining England.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-111)  Scotland won 6½–1.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-112)

### 2007: Ascending to the top 10
Murray reached the fourth round of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Section_8 "2007 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), where he lost a five-set match against No. 2, Rafael Nadal.[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-113)

Following the  [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Sony_Ericsson_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2007 Sony Ericsson Open – Men's Singles"), where he reached the semi-finals,[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-114)  Murray reached the No. 10 ranking on 16 April.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

The British No. 1 sustained tendon damage during his first round match at the  [German Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Qatar_Telecom_German_Open "2007 Qatar Telecom German Open")  in Hamburg. Murray was up 5–1 when he hit a forehand from the back of the court and snapped the tendons in his wrist, leaving him out of action from 15 May until 7 August, thereby missing Wimbledon.[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2007_wrist_injury-116)  During this rest period, Murray rose to No. 8, but by 7 August, he had dropped to No. 14.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

Murray suffered a third round loss at the  [US Open.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Section_3 "2007 US Open – Men's Singles")  At the Masters tournaments, Murray reached the semi-finals of Indian Wells and Miami. At Rome and Cincinnati, Murray exited in the first round whilst going out in the second in Canada. In the final two masters tournaments, Murray exited in the third round in Madrid and he went out in the quarter-finals of Paris. Murray won titles in San Jose and St. Petersburg.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-117)  He also reached the final of tournaments in Doha and Metz, finishing the season ranked 11th in the world.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

In November, Murray split with his coach Brad Gilbert and added a team of experts along with  [Miles Maclagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Maclagan "Miles Maclagan"), his main coach.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-118)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-119)

### 2008: First major final and Masters titles

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg)

Murray at the 2008 US Open

In 2008, Murray suffered a first round loss at the Australian Open to eventual runner-up Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, and a third round loss at the French Open to  [Nicolás Almagro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Almagro "Nicolás Almagro").[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-120)  Murray then made his first Grand Slam quarter-final at Wimbledon before making his first final at the US Open. During the tournament in New York, Murray claimed his first win over Nadal. That victory meant that he'd become the first player from Britain since Greg Rusedski in 1997 to reach a major final.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-121)  In his first Grand Slam final Murray suffered a straight sets loss to Federer.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated2-122)[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-123)  At the  [Beijing Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics"), Murray suffered one of the worst defeats of his career, losing his first round singles match to No. 77  [Yen-hsun Lu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yen-hsun_Lu "Yen-hsun Lu")  of Taiwan in straight sets. That abject defeat was still on his mind in a BBC interview five years later – despite an intervening Olympic gold medal and a head-to-head win – when he met the same player (now ranked No. 75) in the second round of Wimbledon 2013.[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-124)

In the Masters tournaments Murray went out in round four in Indian Wells and the first round of Miami. In the clay Masters Murray made the third round of Monte Carlo and Hamburg and the second of Rome. On the American hard court swing Murray made the semi-finals of Toronto before winning his first Masters shield in Cincinnati. He added another shield to his collection in Madrid;[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-125)  before losing in the quarter-finals of Paris. Now at No. 4 in the world, Murray qualified for the first time for the  [Masters Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"). He played well in defeating an injured Federer[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-126)  but lost to Davydenko in the semi-finals.[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-127)  Murray ended 2008 ranked No. 4. Murray also won tournaments in Doha, Marseille and St Petersburg.

### 2009: Ascent to world No. 2, two Masters titles

Murray opened the 2009 season with a successful defence of his title at the  [Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2009 Qatar ExxonMobil Open")  in  [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doha "Doha"), defeating Andy Roddick in straight sets.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-128)  At the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), Murray made it to the fourth round, losing to  [Fernando Verdasco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Verdasco "Fernando Verdasco").[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-129)  Murray won his eleventh career title in  [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2009 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament"), defeating No. 1, Nadal in three sets.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-130)  Murray next went to Dubai but withdrew before the quarter-finals with a re-occurrence of a virus that had affected him at the Australian Open.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-131)  The virus caused Murray to miss a  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  tie in Glasgow. Murray then lost in the finals to Nadal at  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Indian_Wells_Masters "2009 Indian Wells Masters"),[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-132)  but won a week later in Miami over Djokovic for another masters title.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Andy_Murray_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg)

Murray made the quarter-finals of the  [2009 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open "2009 French Open")

In the lead-up to the French Open, Murray beat No. 9,  [Nikolay Davydenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolay_Davydenko "Nikolay Davydenko")  at the  [Monte Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles#Finals "2009 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), the first time he had beaten a top ten player on clay,[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Davydenko-133)  though he lost to Nadal in the semi-finals. Murray was upset in round two of the  [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles")  by qualifier  [Juan Mónaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_M%C3%B3naco "Juan Mónaco"), and he reached the quarter-finals of the  [Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open"), losing to  [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"). During this time Murray achieved the highest ever ranking of a British male in the  [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era")  when he reached the No. 3 ranking on 11 May 2009.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-tennis1-134)  Murray reached the quarter-finals of the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Finals "2009 French Open – Men's Singles"), but was defeated by  [Fernando González](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez "Fernando González")  in four sets.

Murray won a title for the first time on  [grass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawn_Tennis "Lawn Tennis")  at  [Queen's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_AEGON_Championships "2009 AEGON Championships")  and became the first British winner of the tournament since 1938. In the final Murray defeated American  [James Blake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Blake_(tennis) "James Blake (tennis)").[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-135)  At Wimbledon, against Stanislas Wawrinka, Murray's fourth round match was the first match to be played entirely under Wimbledon's  [retractable roof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retractable_roof "Retractable roof"). This also enabled it to be the then latest finishing match ever at Wimbledon, a record he would go on to eclipse three years later in a second round match against Marcos Baghdatis.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-136)  However Murray lost a tight semi-final to Andy Roddick.

Murray returned to action in  [Montreal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Rogers_Cup "2008 Rogers Cup"), defeating del Potro in three sets to take the title.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-137)  After this victory, he overtook Nadal in the rankings and held the number two position until the start of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)").[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-atpworldtour-138)  Murray followed the Masters win playing at the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters"), where he lost to Federer. At the US Open, Murray was hampered by a wrist injury and suffered a straight-sets loss to Čilić.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Wrist_injury_US_Open_2009-139)  Murray won both his singles matches, and lost at doubles in the Davis Cup against Poland,[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-140)  but then missed six weeks with a wrist injury.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Valencia_2009-141)

In November, Murray won at  [Valencia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Valencia_Open_500 "2009 Valencia Open 500"),[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Valencia_2009-141)[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-142)  but bowed out in round two of the Paris Masters. To end the season, Murray did not make it out of the round robin at the  [World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2009 ATP World Tour Finals")  in London.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-143)  He ended the year ranked #4 for the second consecutive year.

### 2010: Hopman Cup and Australian Open finals

Murray and  [Laura Robson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Robson "Laura Robson")  represented Britain at the  [Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Hopman_Cup "2010 Hopman Cup"). The pair progressed to the final, where they were beaten by Spain.[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-144)  At the Australian Open Murray beat Nadal and Čilić before losing in the final to No. 1 Roger Federer.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2010AO-145)

I can cry like Roger, it's just a shame I can't play like him.

Andy Murray during his runner's up speech at the 2010 Australian Open.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-146)

At the  [BNP Paribas Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BNP_Paribas_Open "BNP Paribas Open")  in Indian Wells, Murray reached the quarter-finals, losing to  [Robin Söderling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_S%C3%B6derling "Robin Söderling")  in straight sets. Murray next played at the  [2010 Sony Ericsson Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Sony_Ericsson_Open "2010 Sony Ericsson Open"), but lost his first match of the tournament to  [Mardy Fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mardy_Fish "Mardy Fish"), afterwards saying that his mind hadn't been fully on tennis.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-147)  At the  [Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters"), Murray suffered another first match loss, this time to  [Philipp Kohlschreiber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Kohlschreiber "Philipp Kohlschreiber"). He entered the doubles competition with  [Ross Hutchins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ross_Hutchins "Ross Hutchins"); the duo lost to the  [Bryan Brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryan_Brothers "Bryan Brothers")  on a champions tie-breaker. Murray reached the third round in the Rome Masters, and the quarter-finals at the Madrid Masters, losing both times to  [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer").[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-148)[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-149)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Australian_Open_2010_Quarterfinals_Nadal_Vs_Murray_3.jpg/220px-Australian_Open_2010_Quarterfinals_Nadal_Vs_Murray_3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Australian_Open_2010_Quarterfinals_Nadal_Vs_Murray_3.jpg)

Murray reached his second Grand Slam Final in Australia

After playing  [an exhibition match](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masters_Guinot-Mary_Cohr#2010 "Masters Guinot-Mary Cohr"), Murray started the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_French_Open "2010 French Open")  with three tough wins, before losing in straight sets to  [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych")  in the fourth round.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-150)  In  [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_AEGON_Championships "2010 AEGON Championships"), Murray progressed to the third round, where he faced Mardy Fish. At 3–3 in the final set with momentum going Murray's way (he had just come back from 3–0 down), the match was called off for bad light, leaving Murray fuming. Coming back the next day, Murray was edged out by the eventual finalist in a tie-breaker for his second defeat by him in the year.[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-151)[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-152)  At Wimbledon, Murray progressed to the semi-finals, losing to Nadal in straight sets.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-153)  On 27 July 2010, Murray and his coach Maclagan split, and Murray replaced him with  [Àlex Corretja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%80lex_Corretja "Àlex Corretja").[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-154)

Starting the US hard-court season with the  [2010 Farmers Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Farmers_Classic "2010 Farmers Classic"), Murray reached the final but lost against  [Sam Querrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Querrey "Sam Querrey")  in three sets. This was his first loss to Querrey in five career meetings.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-155)  In Canada, Murray became the first player since  [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi")  in 1995 to defend the  [Canadian Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Cup_(tennis) "Rogers Cup (tennis)"). Murray defeated Nadal and then Federer in straight sets, ending his eight-month title drought.[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-156)  At the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters_and_Women%27s_Open "2010 Western & Southern Financial Group Masters and Women's Open"), Murray first complained about the speed of the court,[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-157)  and then in a quarter-final match with Fish, Murray complained that the organisers refused to put the match on later in the day[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-158)  With temperatures reaching 33 °C in the shade, Murray won the first set in a tie-breaker but began to feel ill. The doctor was called on court to actively cool Murray down. Murray said after the match that he had considered retiring. He lost the second set, but forced a final-set tie-breaker, before Fish won.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-hot_cincy-159)  After losing to Stanislas Wawrinka in the third round of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_(tennis) "2010 US Open (tennis)"), questions about Murray's conditioning arose, as he called the trainer out twice during the match.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-160)

His next event was the  [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_China_Open_(tennis) "2010 China Open (tennis)")  in Beijing, where Murray reached the quarter-finals, losing to  [Ivan Ljubičić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Ljubi%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Ivan Ljubičić").[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-161)  Murray then won the  [Shanghai Rolex Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters "2010 Shanghai Rolex Masters")  dismissing Roger Federer in straight sets.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-162)  He did not drop a single set throughout the event. Murray returned to Spain to defend his title at the  [Valencia Open 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Valencia_Open_500 "2010 Valencia Open 500")  but lost in the second round to Juan Mónaco.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-163)  However, in doubles, Murray partnered his brother Jamie Murray to the final, where they defeated  [Mahesh Bhupathi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahesh_Bhupathi "Mahesh Bhupathi")  and  [Max Mirnyi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Mirnyi "Max Mirnyi"). The victory was Murray's first doubles title and the second time he had reached a final with his brother.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-164)

Murray reached the quarter-finals at the  [BNP Paribas Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_BNP_Paribas_Masters "2010 BNP Paribas Masters")  losing to Gaël Monfils in three sets. Combined with his exit and Söderling's taking the title, Murray found himself pushed down a spot in the rankings, to No. 5 from No. 4.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-165)  At the  [Tour finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2010 ATP World Tour Finals")  in London, Murray went 2–1 in round robin play before facing Nadal in the semi-final. They battled for over three hours, before Murray fell to the Spaniard in a final-set tie-breaker, bringing an end to his season.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-166)  He ended the year ranked #4 for the third consecutive year.

### 2011: Consistency in slams, two more Masters

Murray and Laura Robson lost in the round-robin stage  [2011 Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Hopman_Cup "2011 Hopman Cup"), losing all three ties even though Murray won all of his singles matches. Then Murray, along with other stars such as Federer, Nadal, and Djokovic, participated in the  [Rally for Relief event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open#Rally_for_Relief "2011 Australian Open")  to help raise money for the flood victims in Queensland.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-167)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Andy_and_Jamie_Murray.jpg/170px-Andy_and_Jamie_Murray.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_and_Jamie_Murray.jpg)

Murray with his brother  [Jamie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Murray "Jamie Murray")  (left) at the 2011 Japan Open

Seeded fifth in the  [2011 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2011 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), Murray met former champion Novak Djokovic in the final and was defeated in straight sets. In  [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2011 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament"), he was defeated by  [Marcos Baghdatis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcos_Baghdatis "Marcos Baghdatis")  in the first round.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-168)  Murray reached the semi-finals of the doubles tournament with his brother Jamie. Murray lost to qualifiers in the first rounds at the Masters Series events in  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_BNP_Paribas_Open "2011 BNP Paribas Open")  and  [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Sony_Ericsson_Open "2011 Sony Ericsson Open"), after which he split with coach Àlex Corretja.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-169)

Murray returned to form at the  [Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters"), but lost to Nadal in the semi-finals.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-170)  Murray sustained an elbow injury before the match and subsequently withdrew from the  [2011 Barcelona Open Banco Sabadell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Barcelona_Open_Banco_Sabadell "2011 Barcelona Open Banco Sabadell")  due to the injury.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-171)  Murray lost in the third round at the  [Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid_Open_(tennis) "Madrid Open (tennis)"), but made it to the semi-finals of the  [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome_Masters "Rome Masters"), where he lost to Novak Djokovic.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2011atp-172)

At the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2011 French Open – Men's Singles"), Murray won two tough early matches, before losing in his first semi-final at Roland Garros, against Rafael Nadal.[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-173)[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-174)[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-175)

Murray defeated Jo-Wilfried Tsonga to win his second Queen's Club title.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-176)  At  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles"), Murray lost in the semi-final to Nadal, despite taking the first set.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-177)  At the Davis Cup tie between Great Britain and Luxembourg, Murray led the British team to victory.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-178)  Murray was the two-time defending  [2011 Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rogers_Cup "2011 Rogers Cup")  champion, but lost in the second round to South African  [Kevin Anderson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_(tennis) "Kevin Anderson (tennis)").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-179)  However, the following week, he won the  [2011 Western & Southern Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2011 Western & Southern Open")  after Novak Djokovic retired due to injury.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-djinjury-180)  At the  [2011 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis) "2011 US Open (tennis)"), Murray battled from two sets down to win a five-set second-round encounter with  [Robin Haase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Haase "Robin Haase"), but lost in the semi-finals to Rafael Nadal in four sets.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-181)  This was the first time in his career that Andy had reached the quarter-finals, or better, at all four slams in a calendar year.

Murray easily won the small 250-class  [Thailand Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_PTT_Thailand_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2011 PTT Thailand Open – Singles"), and the following week he won his third title in four tournaments at the  [Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2011 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Singles"). His opponent in the final was Rafael Nadal, whom he beat for the first time in the year in three sets. Murray then won the doubles with his brother Jamie Murray, becoming the first person in the 2011 season to capture both singles and doubles titles at the same tournament. Murray then successfully defended his  [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2011 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles")  crown with a straight-sets victory over David Ferrer in the final. At the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"), Murray lost to David Ferrer in straight sets and withdrew from the tournament after the loss with a groin pull. Murray ended the year ranked #4, behind Djokovic, Nadal, and Federer, for the fourth consecutive year.

### 2012: Olympic Gold, US Open champion and Wimbledon runner-up

Main article:  [2012 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2012 Andy Murray tennis season")

With  [Ivan Lendl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Lendl "Ivan Lendl")  as his new full-time coach,[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-182)  Murray began the season by playing in the  [2012 Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Brisbane_International "2012 Brisbane International"). He overcame a slow start in his first two matches to win his 22nd title by beating  [Alexandr Dolgopolov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandr_Dolgopolov "Alexandr Dolgopolov")  in the final.[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-183)  In doubles, he lost in the quarter-finals against second seeds  [Jürgen Melzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Melzer "Jürgen Melzer")  and  [Philipp Petzschner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Petzschner "Philipp Petzschner")  in a tight match.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-184)  After an exhibition tournament,[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-185)  Murray made it to the semi-finals of the  [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), where he was defeated by Djokovic in a four-hour-and 50-minute match.[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-186)

At the  [Dubai Duty Free Tennis Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubai_Tennis_Championships "Dubai Tennis Championships"), Murray defeated Djokovic in the semi-finals, but lost in the final to Roger Federer.[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-187)  After an early defeat at the  [BNP Paribas Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BNP_Paribas_Open "BNP Paribas Open"), Murray made the final of the  [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Masters "Miami Masters"), losing to Djokovic.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2012ATP-188)  Murray then had quarter-final losses at the Monte Carlo Masters and Barcelona Open, and a third round loss at the  [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles").[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-189)[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-190)[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-191)  Murray battled back spasms throughout the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 French Open – Men's Singles"), and in the quarter-finals, he was beaten by David Ferrer.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-192)

Murray lost in the opening round of the  [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships")  to No. 65  [Nicolas Mahut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolas_Mahut "Nicolas Mahut").[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-193)  At  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles"), Murray set the then record for the latest finish at the championships when he completed a four-set victory over Marcos Baghdatis at 23:02 BST, which was eclipsed by the 2018 Wimbledon men's singles semi-finals which saw play being completed at 23:03 BST.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated1-194)  Murray beat  [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga")  in the semi-final in four sets to become the first male British player to reach the final of Wimbledon since  [Bunny Austin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunny_Austin "Bunny Austin")  in 1938.[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-195)  In the final, he faced Federer, but after taking the first set, he lost the match in four sets.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-196)

Murray returned to Wimbledon within weeks, this time to compete in the  [London 2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles. He partnered his brother Jamie Murray in doubles and suffered a first-round exit to  [Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austria_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Austria at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  (Jürgen Melzer and  [Alexander Peya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Peya "Alexander Peya")) in three sets.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-197)  In the mixed doubles, Murray was partnered by  [Laura Robson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Robson "Laura Robson"). They made it all the way to the finals where they lost to the  [Belarusian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belarus_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Belarus at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  top seeds ([Victoria Azarenka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Azarenka "Victoria Azarenka")  and Max Mirnyi) in three sets, settling for the silver medal. In singles, Murray lost only one set on his way to the finals where he met Federer, defeating him in straight sets, for the loss of just 7 games.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2012ATP-188)  By winning the Olympic gold medal, Murray became the first British man to win the Olympic singles gold medal in tennis since  [Josiah Ritchie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josiah_Ritchie "Josiah Ritchie")  in 1908, and only the 7th man in the open era to win two medals at the same Olympic Games.[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-198)  Murray retired early in the  [Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Rogers Cup – Men's Singles")  due to a knee injury, and was beaten by unseeded  [Jérémy Chardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%A9my_Chardy "Jérémy Chardy")  at the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Western & Southern Open – Men's Singles")  in straight sets.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Andy_Murray_2012_%28cropped%29_2.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_2012_%28cropped%29_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_2012_(cropped)_2.jpg)

Murray at the  [2012 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)")  where he won his first major title

He next competed in the final major of the season at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)"). He cruised through his opening two rounds in straight sets against  [Alex Bogomolov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Bogomolov "Alex Bogomolov")  and  [Ivan Dodig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Dodig "Ivan Dodig"), before facing a tough four-set battle with  [Feliciano López](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feliciano_L%C3%B3pez "Feliciano López"), where Murray had to win three tie-breakers. In the fourth round, he defeated the Canadian  [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic")  in straight sets, and then in the quarter-finals, had to come from a set and two breaks down against Marin Čilić to prevail in four. In the semi-finals, he defeated Tomáš Berdych in a long-fought match that lasted almost four hours, to reach his second consecutive Grand Slam final. Murray defeated Djokovic in five sets, becoming the first British man to win a Grand Slam final since Fred Perry in 1936,[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-199)  and the first Scottish-born player to win a Grand Slam final since  [Harold Mahony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Mahony "Harold Mahony")  in 1896.[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-200)  The win would also set several records for Murray: it involved the longest tiebreak in US Open final history at 12–10 in the first set, it made Murray the first man ever to win an Olympic gold medal and the US Open in the same year, and it tied with the  [1988 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "1988 US Open – Men's Singles")  final (in which Murray's coach Lendl competed) as the  [longest final in the tournament's history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_tennis_match_records#Men_4 "Longest tennis match records").[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-201)  By defeating Djokovic in the  [final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 US Open – Men's singles final"), Murray achieved his 100th Grand Slam match win of his career. The victory made Murray part of the "[Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")" according to many pundits and contemporaries, including Novak Djokovic.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-202)[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-203)

In his first tournament after the US Open, Murray reached the semi-finals of the  [Rakuten Japan Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2012 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Singles")  after entering as defending champion. He was beaten by Milos Raonic in a close three-set match. He was defending champion in the  [doubles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Doubles "2012 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Doubles")  with his brother Jamie. However, they were knocked out in the quarter-finals by top seeds  [Leander Paes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leander_Paes "Leander Paes")  and  [Radek Štěpánek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radek_%C5%A0t%C4%9Bp%C3%A1nek "Radek Štěpánek"). At the penultimate Masters 1000 tournament of the year in Shanghai, after receiving a bye into round two, Murray's first match was due to be played against  [Florian Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florian_Mayer "Florian Mayer"). However, Mayer had to pull out due to injury, giving Murray a walkover into round three. After beating Alexandr Dolgopolov in the third round, he then overcame Radek Štěpánek in a three-set quarter-final. Murray next faced Roger Federer in the semi-finals, whom he defeated in straight sets to set up a second consecutive final against Djokovic, and his third consecutive Shanghai final. After failing to capitalise on five match points, Murray eventually lost in three sets, bringing to an end his 12–0 winning streak at the competition.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-204)[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-205)  When Nadal pulled out of both the Paris Masters and the Year-End Championships,[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-206)  Murray finished the year at No. 3, after four years at No. 4. This was the first time Murray had finished the year higher than No. 4. At the  _[BBC Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Sports Personality of the Year")_  Murray found himself voted third overall, ahead of  [Mo Farah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah "Mo Farah").[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-207)  Murray won the World Breakthrough of the Year at the Laureus World Sports Awards.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-208)

Murray was appointed  [Officer of the Order of the British Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order of the British Empire")  (OBE) in the  [2013 New Year Honours](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_New_Year_Honours "2013 New Year Honours")  for services to tennis.[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Honours2013-209)[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-210)[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-211)

### 2013: Wimbledon champion and back surgery

Main article:  [2013 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2013 Andy Murray tennis season")
