He said that he had been suffering with hip pain on a daily basis, and that it caused him to struggle with tasks like putting his shoes and socks on.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-surprise-396)  He spoke of the possibility of a second hip surgery, but expressed doubt this would be a viable option to prolong his career, merely allowing him to "have a better quality of life, and be out of pain".[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbclast19-397)  He hoped to make it through to  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships "2019 Wimbledon Championships"),[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbclast19-397)[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-lastword19-398)  but that the Australian Open could be his final tournament if he was not able to last until the summer, stating: "I'm not sure I can play through the pain for another four or five months".[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-surprise-396)  Active and retired tennis players, including Juan Martín del Potro, Kyle Edmund,  [Bilie Jean King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billie_Jean_King "Billie Jean King")  and the other members of the 'Big Four' paid tribute to Murray upon his announcement.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-399)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-400)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-401)

Murray entered the singles of the Australian Open, however lost his opening match against 22nd seed  [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut")  in a four-hour, five-set 'epic'. At its conclusion, a video montage of tributes featuring other top players Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic,  [Sloane Stephens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sloane_Stephens "Sloane Stephens")  and  [Caroline Wozniacki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki "Caroline Wozniacki")  played in deference to his impending retirement.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-402)  In his post-match interview, he stated that he was considering a second hip surgery, and had not yet ruled out a return to the sport upon recovering from the operation.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-403)

[Bob Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Bryan "Bob Bryan")  urged Murray to have the "[Birmingham hip (BHR)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham_Hip_Resurfacing "Birmingham Hip Resurfacing")" operation he underwent in August 2018, involving a cobalt-chrome metal cap being placed over the femur with a matching metal cup in the acetabulum (a conservative bone-saving alternative to a traditional Total Hip Replacement). Bryan informed Murray that the BHR would improve his quality of life and may help him return to the professional tennis tour.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-404)  On 29 January, Murray announced on Instagram that he had undergone hip resurfacing surgery in London and hoped that it would "be the end of my hip pain."[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-405)  On 4 February, in an interview with  _[The Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_,  [Professor Derek McMinn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_McMinn "Derek McMinn"), who invented the BHR implant and procedure, gave the opinion that Murray's chances of returning to competitive tennis should be "in the high 90 per cent".[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-406)  On 7 March, Murray stated in an interview that he was now free of pain in his hip as a result of the surgery and may therefore return to playing competitive tennis, but that any potential Wimbledon return would be dependent on how his hip felt, and that he would not rush his comeback and may test his condition by playing doubles.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-407)

On 16 May 2019, Murray received his knighthood from  [Prince Charles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Charles "Prince Charles")  at  [Buckingham Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace"), two years after he was awarded the honour.[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-408)

Murray returned to the professional tennis circuit in June, entering the doubles competition of the  [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Queen%27s_Club_Championships_%E2%80%93_Doubles "2019 Queen's Club Championships – Doubles")  alongside  [Feliciano Lopez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feliciano_Lopez "Feliciano Lopez").[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-409)  The duo won their first round match against the top seeds  [Juan Sebastián Cabal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Cabal "Juan Sebastián Cabal")  and  [Robert Farah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Farah_(tennis) "Robert Farah (tennis)")  in straight sets and then beat the defending champions  [John Peers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Peers "John Peers")  and  [Henri Kontinen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henri_Kontinen "Henri Kontinen")  in the semi finals.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-410)  Murray and Lopez went on to win the tournament by defeating  [Rajeev Ram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajeev_Ram "Rajeev Ram")  and  [Joe Salisbury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Salisbury "Joe Salisbury")  in a final set champions tiebreak.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-411)  Following the win, Murray stated that his "hip felt great" and that "there was no pain."[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-412)  Murray continued his comeback from injury by partnering  [Marcelo Melo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcelo_Melo "Marcelo Melo")  in the doubles at the  [Eastbourne International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Eastbourne_International_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles "2019 Eastbourne International – Men's Doubles")  where they lost in the first round against Cabal and Farah.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-413)  At the  [2019 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships "2019 Wimbledon Championships"), Murray entered the men's doubles and mixed doubles events. In the  [men's doubles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Doubles")  he partnered  [Pierre-Hugues Herbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre-Hugues_Herbert "Pierre-Hugues Herbert")  and was eliminated in the second round, while his  [mixed doubles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Mixed_Doubles "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Mixed Doubles")  partnership with  [Serena Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serena_Williams "Serena Williams")  ended with a third round defeat to top seeds  [Bruno Soares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Soares "Bruno Soares")  and  [Nicole Melichar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicole_Melichar "Nicole Melichar").[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-414)

After Murray's Wimbledon campaign, he and his brother Jamie participated in the Citi Open doubles, where they defeated  [Edouard Roger-Vasselin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edouard_Roger-Vasselin "Edouard Roger-Vasselin")  and  [Nicolas Mahut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolas_Mahut "Nicolas Mahut")  before losing to  [Michael Venus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Venus_(tennis) "Michael Venus (tennis)")  and  [Raven Klaasen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raven_Klaasen "Raven Klaasen")  in the round of 16. His next tournament at the  [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Open_(tennis) "Canadian Open (tennis)")  renewed his partnership with  [Feliciano Lopez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feliciano_Lopez "Feliciano Lopez")  where they defeated  [Lukasz Kubot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lukasz_Kubot "Lukasz Kubot")  and  [Marcelo Melo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcelo_Melo "Marcelo Melo")  and lost to  [Fabrice Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabrice_Martin "Fabrice Martin")  and  [Jeremy Chardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeremy_Chardy "Jeremy Chardy"). Following the conclusion of the tournament, Murray stated his return to the singles competition at the Western and Southern Open and revealed his plans to play in China in the autumn.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-415)  In his first singles match since the 2019 Australian Open, Murray faced  [Richard Gasquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Gasquet "Richard Gasquet")  in the first round of the  [2019 Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Western_and_Southern_Open_Men%27s_Singles "2019 Western and Southern Open Men's Singles"), losing in straight sets.[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-416)  In the quarter-final of the Cincinnati doubles tournament, Andy Murray and Feliciano López met Jamie Murray and  [Neal Skupski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neal_Skupski "Neal Skupski")  in only the second match between the siblings in their senior careers; Jamie and Skupski won in three sets to progress, with Andy stating afterwards that he would now concentrate his efforts on returning to the singles tour.[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-417)  Murray then played at the  [2019 Winston-Salem Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Winston-Salem_Open "2019 Winston-Salem Open"), where he faced  [Tennys Sandgren](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennys_Sandgren "Tennys Sandgren")  in the first round. Murray lost in straight sets, though the score was close. Murray then contemplated dropping down to Challenger level, skipping the US Open entirely to focus on two tournaments happening concurrently. Murray opted to play at the  [2019 Rafa Nadal Open Banc Sabadell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Rafa_Nadal_Open_Banc_Sabadell "2019 Rafa Nadal Open Banc Sabadell")  Challenger event, the first time he had competed on the second tier Challenger Tour since 2005.[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-418)  In the first round of the event, Murray defeated 17-year-old Imran Sibille in straight sets in under 43 minutes to record his first singles victory since his hip surgery.[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-BBC260819-419)  He lost to  [Matteo Viola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matteo_Viola "Matteo Viola")  in the third round.[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-420)

In September 2019, Murray participated in the inaugural  [Zhuhai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Zhuhai_Championships "2019 Zhuhai Championships"), losing to eventual champion  [Alex de Minaur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_de_Minaur "Alex de Minaur")  in the second round. He also participated in the China Open, where he recorded a win against  [Matteo Berrettini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matteo_Berrettini "Matteo Berrettini"), ranked 13th in the world, but he was eliminated by eventual champion  [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem")  in the quarter-final.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-421)  Murray lost against 12th ranked  [Fabio Fognini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabio_Fognini "Fabio Fognini")  in the second round of the Shanghai Open, before winning the first title after his operation in the  [European Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Open_(tennis) "European Open (tennis)")  in October 2019, beating three-time Grand Slam winner  [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka")  in the final. In November 2019, he represented Great Britain for the first time since 2016 after being named in the squad for the  [2019 Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Davis_Cup "2019 Davis Cup")  finals;[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-422)  however, he was only able to play one rubber in Great Britain's run to the semi-finals.

At the end of November 2019, a television documentary,  _Andy Murray: Resurfacing_, was released on the  [Amazon Prime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Video "Prime Video")  platform, detailing Murray's various attempts to overcome his hip injury over a two-year period from his defeat at Wimbledon in 2017 to his doubles victory at Queen's Club in 2019.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-423)[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-424)  In late December, Murray's team confirmed that the pelvic injury which had curtailed his involvement in the Davis Cup would also prevent him from entering the upcoming  [2020 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Australian_Open "2020 Australian Open")  and the inaugural  [ATP Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Cup "ATP Cup").[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-425)

## Rivalries

See also:  [Big Four (tennis)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")

### Murray vs. Djokovic
Main article:  [Djokovic–Murray rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Murray_rivalry "Djokovic–Murray rivalry")

[Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  and Murray have met 36 times with Djokovic leading 25–11.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Novak_Djokovic_VS_Andy_Murray-426)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-427)  Djokovic leads 5–1 on clay, 20–8 on hard courts, and Murray leads 2–0 on grass. The two are almost exactly the same age, with Murray being only a week older than Djokovic. They went to training camp together, and Murray won the first match they ever played as teenagers. The pair have met 19 times in finals, with Djokovic leading 11–8.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Novak_Djokovic_VS_Andy_Murray-426)  Ten of the finals were at  [ATP Masters 1000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Masters_1000 "ATP Masters 1000")  events, and they are tied at 5–5. They have met in seven major finals: The  [2011 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open "2011 Australian Open"), the  [2012 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)"), the  [2013 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open "2013 Australian Open"), the  [2013 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships "2013 Wimbledon Championships"), the  [2015 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open "2015 Australian Open"), the  [2016 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Australian_Open "2016 Australian Open"), and the  [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open "2016 French Open"). Djokovic has won in Australia four times and their single French open final, Murray emerged as the victor at the US Open and Wimbledon. The former of Murray's victories was the longest ever final at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), tying with the 1988 final played between Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander at 4 hours and 53 minutes, while the latter was notable for being the first home triumph in men's singles at  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  since 1936.

They also played a nearly five-hour long semi-final match in the  [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open "2012 Australian Open"), which Djokovic won 7–5 in the fifth set after Murray led 2 sets to 1. Murray and Djokovic met again in 2012 at the  [London 2012 Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"), with Murray winning in straight sets. During the final of the  [2012 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters "2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters"), Murray held five championship points in the second set, however Djokovic saved each of them, forcing a deciding set. He eventually prevailed to win his first Shanghai Masters title, ending Murray's 12–0 winning streak at the event. The three set matches they played in  [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis) "Italian Open (tennis)")  and  [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Masters_(tennis) "Shanghai Masters (tennis)")  in  [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles")  and  [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles")  respectively were voted the ATP World Tour Match of the Year for each respective season.[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-428)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-429)  Due to the tight competition between 2008 and 2013, many saw this as the emerging rivalry.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-430)[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-431)  Djokovic went on to dominate the rivalry after the 2013 Wimbledon final, winning 13 of their last 16 matches. In 2016, Murray suffered his 4th loss (his 5th total) in the final of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Australian Open – Men's Singles")  from Djokovic, then the Serbian defeated the British player in four sets in the  [Roland Garros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 French Open – Men's Singles")  final, where Djokovic won his first Roland Garros title and completed the Career Grand Slam.[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-432)[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-433)Murray and Djokovic met in the final at the year's end  [final of the ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles")  for the first time in their rivalry, where the winner would be granted the Year-end No. 1 status. Djokovic, dropped only one set en route to the final at the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"), but lost in straight sets to Murray, who finished the year at No. 1 and became the first British player to achieve this feat.

### Murray vs. Federer

Murray and  [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer")  have met 25 times with Federer leading 14–11. Federer leads 12–10 on hard courts, 2–1 on grass, and they have never met on clay. After Federer won the first professional match they played, Murray dominated the first half of the rivalry, winning 8 of their first 13 matches from 2005 until 2010. The second half of the rivalry has been dominated by Federer, who since won 9 of their last 12 matches from 2010, and has led their rivalry since the  [2014 ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2014 ATP World Tour Finals").[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-h2hFed-434)  Federer leads 5–3 in finals, having won each of their Grand Slam Final meetings at the  [2008 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_US_Open_(tennis) "2008 US Open (tennis)")[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated2-122)  and  [2010 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Australian_Open "2010 Australian Open"), both of which Federer won in straight sets, and the  [2012 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships "2012 Wimbledon Championships"), where Murray took the first set, but ended up losing in 4 sets. Murray leads 6–3 in ATP 1000 tournaments and 2–0 in finals. They have met five times at the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"), with Murray winning in Shanghai in 2008[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-435)  and Federer coming out victorious in London in 2009, 2010, 2012, and in 2014.

In August 2012, Murray met Federer in the  [final of the London 2012 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles")  at Wimbledon Centre Court, just four weeks after the  [2012 Wimbledon Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles final"), in which Federer had defeated Murray to win his record-tying 7th title at the All-England Club. Murray defeated Federer in straight sets to win the gold medal, denying Federer a  [Career Golden Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Career_Golden_Slam "Career Golden Slam"). In 2013 Murray beat Federer for the first time in a major in the semi-finals of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open "2013 Australian Open"), prevailing in five sets after Federer had come back twice from a set down.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-436)  Their last grand slam meeting was at the  [2015 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships "2015 Wimbledon Championships")  semi-finals, where a dominant Federer defeated Murray in straight sets, earning a place in his 10th Wimbledon final. Murray is one of only three players to have recorded 10 or more victories over Federer, the other two being Nadal and Djokovic. Their most recent meeting took place at the  [2015 Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2015 Western & Southern Open")  semi-finals, with Federer winning the match in two close sets, recording his fifth consecutive victory over Murray.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-h2hFed-434)

### Murray vs. Nadal

Murray has played against  [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal")  on 24 occasions since  [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_ATP_Tour "2007 ATP Tour"), with Nadal leading 17–7. Nadal leads 7–2 on clay, 3–0 on grass and 7–5 on hard courts. The pair regularly meet at  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  level, with nine out of their twenty-four meetings coming in slams, with Nadal leading 7–2 (3–0 at  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"), 2–0 at the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open "French Open"), 1–1 at the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open")  and 1–1 at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)")).[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-437)  Eight of these nine appearances have been at quarter-final and semi-final level. They have never met in a slam final, however, Murray leads 3–1 in  [ATP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals")  finals, with Nadal winning at  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_BNP_Paribas_Open "2009 BNP Paribas Open")  in  [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ATP_World_Tour "2009 ATP World Tour")[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-438)  and Murray winning in  [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2009 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament")  the same year,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-439)  [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships "2011 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships")[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-440)  in  [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_ATP_World_Tour "2011 ATP World Tour"), and at  [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2015 Mutua Madrid Open")  in  [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_ATP_World_Tour "2015 ATP World Tour").

Murray lost three consecutive Grand Slam semi-finals to Nadal in 2011 from the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open "2011 French Open")  to the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis) "2011 US Open (tennis)"). The pair had not met for three years since the final of the  [2011 Japan Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships "2011 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships")  until the quarter-finals of the  [2014 Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia "2014 Internazionali BNL d'Italia"), although they were scheduled to meet in the semi-final of the  [2012 Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Miami_Masters "2012 Miami Masters")  before Nadal withdrew with injury.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-441)  At the semi-final stage of the  [2014 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_French_Open "2014 French Open"), Nadal triumphed in a dominant straight sets win for the loss of just 6 games. In one of their most recent meetings, Murray beat Nadal for the first time on clay, and the first time in a Masters 1000 final, at the  [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2015 Mutua Madrid Open")  in 2015.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-442)  Murray fell to Nadal in the semi-finals of the  [2016 Monte Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), despite taking the first set.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-443)  Three weeks later they met again at the semi-final stage of the  [2016 Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's Singles"), this time Murray winning the match in straight sets.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-444)

### Murray vs. Wawrinka

Murray and  [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka")  have played 20 times with Murray leading 12–8. Murray leads 8–4 on hard courts and 3–0 on grass courts while Wawrinka leads 4–1 on clay courts. They have also met six times in Grand Slam tournaments with each player winning three matches.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-445)  They have contested some close matches and one of their most notable matches was in the  [2009 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles")  fourth round which Murray won in five sets and was the first men's match to be played under the Wimbledon roof, having the latest finish for a Wimbledon match at the time.[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-446)  Wawrinka also ended Murray's title defense at the  [2013 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 US Open – Men's Singles")  quarter-finals with a comfortable straight sets victory.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-447)  Other close matches the two have contested include the  [2010 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2010 US Open – Men's Singles")  which Wawrinka won in four sets. Murray won the  [2008 Canada Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Rogers_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2008 Rogers Masters – Singles")  and  [2011 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2011 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles").

While Murray has led the majority of the rivalry, Wawrinka won their first two matches and beat Murray three consecutive times between 2013 and 2015, winning all of them in straight sets, until Murray ended the losing streak at the  [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 French Open – Men's Singles"), beating the defending champion Wawrinka in four sets to reach his first ever French Open final and become the first British man to do so since 1937. Their most recent match was played in the final of the  [2019 European Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 European Open – Singles"), which Murray won in three sets. Due to this match-up and since both players each have three Grand Slam titles, Wawrinka has been identified by some, including Djokovic, as a potential contender to turn the  [Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")  tennis quartet into a "Big Five", although Wawrinka himself has downplayed those suggestions, stating that he is still far behind them.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-448)[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-449)

## Playing style

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_%2810%29.jpg/170px-Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_%2810%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_(10).jpg)

At the  [Boodles Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boodles_Challenge "Boodles Challenge"), Stoke Park, June 2012

Murray plays an  [all-court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_strategy#All-court_player "Tennis strategy")  game with an emphasis on  [defensive baseline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterpuncher "Counterpuncher")  play, and in 2009 professional tennis coach  [Paul Annacone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Annacone "Paul Annacone")  stated that Murray "may be the best counterpuncher on tour today."[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-450)[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-No_surface_tension_as_Murray_looks_to_shed_his_feet_of_clay-451)  His strengths include groundstrokes with low error rate, the ability to anticipate and react, and his transition from defence to offence with speed, which enables him to hit winners from defensive positions. His playing style has been likened to that of  [Miloslav Mečíř](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miloslav_Me%C4%8D%C3%AD%C5%99 "Miloslav Mečíř"). Murray also has one of the best two-handed backhands on the tour, with dynamic stroke execution[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-452)  while he primarily uses his forehand, which is more passive, and a sliced backhand to let opponents play into his defensive game before playing more offensively.[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-453)  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")  stated in 2013 that Murray may have the best  [lob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lob_(tennis) "Lob (tennis)")  in the game, succeeding  [Lleyton Hewitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt "Lleyton Hewitt"). Murray's tactics often involve passive exchanges from the baseline. He is capable of injecting sudden pace into his groundstrokes to surprise his opponents who are used to the slow rally. Murray is also one of the top returners in the game, often able to block back fast serves with his excellent reach and ability to anticipate. For this reason, Murray is rarely aced.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-454)

Murray is known for being one of the most intelligent tacticians on the court, often constructing points.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-455)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-456)  Other strengths in his game, although not huge parts of his game, include his  [drop shot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drop_shot "Drop shot")[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-457)  and net game.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-458)  As he plays predominantly from the baseline, he usually approaches the net to  [volley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volley_(tennis) "Volley (tennis)")  when finishing points more quickly.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-459)  Murray is most proficient on a fast surface, like grass, where he has won eight singles titles including the  [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  and the  [2012 Olympic Gold Medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics"), although hard courts are his preferred surface.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-No_surface_tension_as_Murray_looks_to_shed_his_feet_of_clay-451)  He has worked hard since 2008 on improving his clay court game,[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-460)  ultimately winning his first clay titles during 2015 at  [Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BMW_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 BMW Open – Singles")  and  [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's Singles"), as well as reaching his first French Open final during 2016. While Murray's  [serve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serve_(tennis) "Serve (tennis)")  is a major weapon for him, with his first serve reaching speeds of 130 mph or higher on some occasions and winning him many free points,[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-How_Andy_Murray_turned_a_second_serve_into_a_lethal_weapon-461)  it can become inconsistent when hit under pressure,[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-462)  especially with a more vulnerable and slower second serve. Since the 2011 season, under Ivan Lendl's coaching, Murray has played a more offensive game and has also worked to improve his second serve, forehand, consistency and mental game which have all been crucial to his further success.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-How_Andy_Murray_turned_a_second_serve_into_a_lethal_weapon-461)[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-463)[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-464)[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-465)

## Endorsements and equipment

In 2009, German manufacturer  [Adidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas "Adidas")  and Murray signed a five-year-deal worth £30 million. This included wearing their range of tennis shoes.[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-466)  The contract with Adidas allowed Murray to keep his shirt sleeve sponsors  [Shiatzy Chen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shiatzy_Chen "Shiatzy Chen"),  [Royal Bank of Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Royal_Bank_of_Scotland "The Royal Bank of Scotland")  and  [Highland Spring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highland_Spring "Highland Spring"). Before he was signed by Adidas in late 2009, he wore Fred Perry apparel.[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-467)  At the end of their contract together Adidas decided not to re-sign with Murray,[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-468)  and he began a 4-year partnership with athletic apparel company  [Under Armour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Under_Armour "Under Armour")  in December 2014,[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-469)  reportedly worth $25 million.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-470)  Murray signed with Castore for the 2019 season which Murray called his last deal before announcing his retirement.[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-471)[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-472)

Murray uses  [Head](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_(company) "Head (company)")  rackets, and regularly appears in advertisements for the brand.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-473)  He endorses the Head Radical Pro model, whereas his actual playing racket (underneath the various Radical Pro paintjobs) is reported to be a customized pro stock PT57A, derived from the original Pro Tour 630 model, but with a 16×19 string pattern.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-474)[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-475)  The racquet used to be set up extremely heavy at the beginning of his career, but after a 2007 wrist injury its weight was lowered.[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-476)

In June 2012, the Swiss watch manufacturer  [Rado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rado_(watch) "Rado (watch)")  announced that Murray had signed a deal to wear their D-Star 200 model.[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-477)

## Coaches

Murray's coaching staff has changed through the years and are as follows:  [Leon Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Smith_(tennis) "Leon Smith (tennis)")  (1998–2004), Pato Álvarez (2003–2005),  [Mark Petchey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Petchey "Mark Petchey")  (2005–2006),  [Brad Gilbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Gilbert "Brad Gilbert")  (2006–2007),  [Miles Maclagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Maclagan "Miles Maclagan")  (2007–2010),  [Àlex Corretja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%80lex_Corretja "Àlex Corretja")  (2010–2011),  [Ivan Lendl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Lendl "Ivan Lendl")  (2011–2014, 2016–2017),  [Amélie Mauresmo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Am%C3%A9lie_Mauresmo "Amélie Mauresmo")  (2014–2016),  [Jonas Björkman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman "Jonas Björkman")  (2015),[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-478)  [Jamie Delgado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Delgado "Jamie Delgado")  (2016–).[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-479)

## Charitable work

Murray is a founding member of the  [Malaria No More UK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria_No_More_UK "Malaria No More UK")  Leadership Council and helped launch the charity in 2009 with  [David Beckham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Beckham "David Beckham"). Footage from the launch at Wembley Stadium can be seen on YouTube and the charity's website.[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-480)  Murray also made 'Nets Needed', a short public service announcement, for the charity to help raise awareness and funds to help in the fight against malaria.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-481)  Murray has also taken part in several charity tennis events, including the  [Rally for Relief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open#Rally_for_Relief "2011 Australian Open")  events that took place prior to the start of the  [2011 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open "2011 Australian Open").[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-482)

In June 2013, Murray teamed up with former British No. 1 Tim Henman for a charity doubles match against Murray's coach and eight-time grand slam champion Ivan Lendl, and No. 6 Tomáš Berdych at the  [Queen's Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club "Queen's Club")  in London. The event named  [Rally Against Cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Aegon_Championships#Rally_Against_Cancer "2013 Aegon Championships")  was organised to raise money for Royal Marsden Cancer Charity after his best friend and fellow British player Ross Hutchins was diagnosed with  [Hodgkin's lymphoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma "Hodgkin's lymphoma").[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-483)[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-484)  The event took place following the final day of competitive play at the  [AEGON Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Aegon_Championships "2013 Aegon Championships"), on Sunday 16 June. Subsequently, following his victory at the tournament, Murray donated his entire prize money pot to  [The Royal Marsden Cancer Charity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Royal_Marsden_NHS_Foundation_Trust "The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust").[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-485)

In June 2014, following the death of  [Elena Baltacha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elena_Baltacha "Elena Baltacha")  due to  [liver cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liver_cancer "Liver cancer"), Murray featured in an event known as 'Rally for Bally'. Murray played at Queen's Club alongside Victoria Azarenka,  [Martina Hingis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martina_Hingis "Martina Hingis"), Heather Watson and his brother Jamie. The event raised money for the Royal Marsden Cancer Charity and the Elena Baltacha Academy of Tennis. Children from Baltacha's academy took to the court to play alongside Murray.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-486)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-487)  As a result of his various charitable exploits, Murray was awarded the  [Arthur Ashe Humanitarian of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Arthur_Ashe_Humanitarian_award "ATP Arthur Ashe Humanitarian award")  award for 2014.[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-488)

name: Usain
bio:
**Usain St Leo Bolt**,  [OJ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_Jamaica "Order of Jamaica"),  [CD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_Distinction "Order of Distinction")  ([/ˈjuːseɪn/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English");[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-14)  born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican former  [sprinter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sprint_(running) "Sprint (running)"). He is a world record holder in the  [100 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres "100 metres"),  [200 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_metres "200 metres")  and  [4 × 100 metres relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_100_metres_relay "4 × 100 metres relay"). Owing to his achievements and dominance in sprint competition, he is widely considered to be the greatest sprinter of all time.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-15)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-16)[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-17)[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-18)

An eight-time  [Olympic gold medallist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_gold_medalists "List of multiple Olympic gold medalists"), Bolt is the only sprinter to win  [Olympic 100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres_at_the_Olympics "100 metres at the Olympics")  and  [200 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_metres_at_the_Olympics "200 metres at the Olympics")  titles at three consecutive Olympics (2008, 2012 and 2016). In addition he won two 4 × 100 relay gold medals. He gained worldwide fame for his double sprint victory in world record times at the  [2008 Beijing Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics"), which made him the first person to hold both records since  [fully automatic time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_automatic_time "Fully automatic time")  became mandatory.

An eleven-time  [World Champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Championships_in_Athletics "World Championships in Athletics"), he won consecutive  [World Championship 100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres_at_the_World_Championships_in_Athletics "100 metres at the World Championships in Athletics"),  [200 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_metres_at_the_World_Championships_in_Athletics "200 metres at the World Championships in Athletics")  and  [4 × 100 metres relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_100_metres_relay_at_the_World_Championships_in_Athletics "4 × 100 metres relay at the World Championships in Athletics")  gold medals from 2009 to 2015, with the exception of a 100 m  [false start](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_start "False start")  in 2011. He is the  [most successful athlete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics#Multiple_medallist "IAAF World Championships in Athletics")  of the World Championships. Bolt is the first athlete to win four World Championship titles in the 200 m and is the joint-most successful in the 100 m with three titles.

Bolt improved upon his second  [100 m world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_100_metres_world_record_progression "Men's 100 metres world record progression")  of 9.69 with 9.58 seconds in 2009 – the biggest improvement since the start of electronic timing. He has twice broken the  [200 metres world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_200_metres_world_record_progression "Men's 200 metres world record progression"), setting 19.30 in 2008 and 19.19 in 2009. He has helped Jamaica to three  [4 × 100 metres relay world records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metres_relay_world_record_progression "Men's 4 × 100 metres relay world record progression"), with the current record being 36.84 seconds set in 2012. Bolt's most successful event is the 200 m, with three Olympic and four World titles. The 2008 Olympics was his international debut over 100 m; he had earlier won numerous 200 m medals (including  [2007 World Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2007 World Championships in Athletics")  silver) and holds the  [world under-20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_junior_records_in_athletics "List of world junior records in athletics")  and  [world under-18 records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_youth_bests_in_athletics "List of world youth bests in athletics")  for the event.

His achievements as a sprinter have earned him the media nickname "Lightning Bolt", and his awards include the  [IAAF World Athlete of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Athlete_of_the_Year "IAAF World Athlete of the Year"),  [Track & Field Athlete of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%26_Field_Athlete_of_the_Year "Track & Field Athlete of the Year"),  [BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Overseas_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year")  (three times) and  [Laureus World Sportsman of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Sportsman_of_the_Year "Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsman of the Year")  (four times). Bolt retired after the  [2017 World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2017 World Championships in Athletics"), when he finished third in his last solo 100 m race, opted out of the 200 m, and pulled up in the 4×100 m relay final.

Stating that it was his "dream" to play professional  [association football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), in August 2018 Bolt began training with Australian  [A-League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A-League "A-League")  club the  [Central Coast Mariners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Coast_Mariners_FC "Central Coast Mariners FC")  as a  [left-winger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winger_(association_football) "Winger (association football)"). On 12 October 2018, Bolt scored twice for the team in a friendly match. He left the club the following month, and in January 2019 chose not to pursue a career in football.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-19)

## Early years

Bolt was born on 21 August 1986 to parents Wellesley and Jennifer Bolt[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-IAAFProfile-12)  in  [Sherwood Content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sherwood_Content "Sherwood Content"),[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-guardian1-20)  a small town in Jamaica. He has a brother, Sadiki,[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-21)  and a sister, Sherine.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Helps-22)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-si-23)  His parents ran the local grocery store in the rural area, and Bolt spent his time playing  [cricket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket_(sport) "Cricket (sport)")  and  [football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football "Association football")  in the street with his brother,[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-24)  later saying, "When I was young, I didn't really think about anything other than sports."[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-BrillBolt-25)  As a child, Bolt attended Waldensia Primary, where he began showing his sprint potential when he ran in his parish's annual national primary school meet.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  By the age of twelve, Bolt had become the school's fastest runner over the  [100 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres "100 metres")  distance.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-26)

Upon his entry to  [William Knibb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Knibb "William Knibb")  Memorial High School, Bolt continued to focus on other sports, but his cricket coach noticed Bolt's speed on the pitch and urged him to try track and field events.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-BBC10-27)  [Pablo McNeil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_McNeil "Pablo McNeil"), a former Olympic sprint athlete,[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-McNeil-28)  and Dwayne Jarrett coached Bolt,[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Jarrett-29)  encouraging him to focus his energy on improving his athletic abilities. The school had a history of success in athletics with past students, including sprinter  [Michael Green](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Green_(sprinter) "Michael Green (sprinter)").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  Bolt won his first annual  [high school championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-Secondary_Schools_Boys_and_Girls_Championships "Inter-Secondary Schools Boys and Girls Championships")  medal in 2001; he took the silver medal in the  [200 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_m "200 m")  with a time of 22.04 seconds.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  McNeil soon became his primary coach, and the two enjoyed a positive partnership, although McNeil was occasionally frustrated by Bolt's lack of dedication to his training and his penchant for practical jokes.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-McNeil-28)

When Bolt was a boy, he attended Sherwood Content  [Seventh-day Adventist Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church "Seventh-day Adventist Church")  in  [Trelawny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trelawny_Parish "Trelawny Parish"), Jamaica, with his  [mother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother "Mother"). His mother didn't serve  [pork](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pork "Pork")  to him in accordance with Adventist beliefs.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-30)

### Early competitions

Performing for Jamaica in his first Caribbean regional event, Bolt clocked a personal best time of 48.28 s in the  [400 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/400_metres "400 metres")  in the 2001  [CARIFTA Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CARIFTA_Games "CARIFTA Games"), winning a silver medal. The 200 m also yielded a silver, as Bolt finished in 21.81 s.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Carifta-31)

He made his first appearance on the world stage at the  [2001 IAAF World Youth Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_World_Youth_Championships_in_Athletics "2001 World Youth Championships in Athletics")  in  [Debrecen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debrecen "Debrecen"), Hungary. Running in the 200 m event, he failed to qualify for the finals, but he still set a new personal best of 21.73 s.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-32)  Bolt still did not take athletics or himself too seriously, however, and he took his mischievousness to new heights by hiding in the back of a van when he was supposed to be preparing for the 200 m finals at the CARIFTA Trials. He was detained by the police for his practical joke, and there was an outcry from the local community, which blamed coach McNeil for the incident.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-McNeil-28)  However, the controversy subsided, and both McNeil and Bolt went to the CARIFTA Games, where Bolt set championship records in the 200 m and 400 m with times of 21.12 s and 47.33 s, respectively.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Carifta-31)  He continued to set records with 20.61 s and 47.12 s finishes at the  [Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_American_and_Caribbean_Junior_Championships "Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships").[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-33)

Bolt is one of only nine athletes (along with  [Valerie Adams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valerie_Adams "Valerie Adams"),  [Veronica Campbell-Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veronica_Campbell-Brown "Veronica Campbell-Brown"),  [Jacques Freitag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Freitag "Jacques Freitag"),  [Yelena Isinbayeva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelena_Isinbayeva "Yelena Isinbayeva"),  [Jana Pittman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jana_Pittman "Jana Pittman"),  [Dani Samuels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dani_Samuels "Dani Samuels"),  [David Storl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Storl "David Storl"), and  [Kirani James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirani_James "Kirani James")) to win world championships at the youth, junior, and senior level of an athletic event. Former Prime Minister  [P. J. Patterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._J._Patterson "P. J. Patterson")  recognised Bolt's talent and arranged for him to move to  [Kingston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingston,_Jamaica "Kingston, Jamaica"), along with  [Jermaine Gonzales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jermaine_Gonzales "Jermaine Gonzales"), so he could train with the  [Jamaica Amateur Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamaica_Amateur_Athletic_Association "Jamaica Amateur Athletic Association")  (JAAA) at the  [University of Technology, Jamaica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Technology,_Jamaica "University of Technology, Jamaica").[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-McNeil-28)

### Rise to prominence

The  [2002 World Junior Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_World_Junior_Championships_in_Athletics "2002 World Junior Championships in Athletics")  were held in front of a home crowd in Kingston, Jamaica, and Bolt was given a chance to prove his credentials on a world stage. By the age of 15, he had grown to 1.96 metres (6 ft 5 in) tall, and he physically stood out among his peers.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  He won the 200 m in a time of 20.61 s,[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-34)  which was 0.03 s slower than his personal best of 20.58 s, which he set in the 1st round.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-35)  Bolt's 200 m win made him the youngest world-junior gold medallist ever.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Longmore-36)  The expectation from the home crowd had made him so nervous that he had put his shoes on the wrong feet, although he realized the mistake before the race began[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-37). However, it turned out to be a revelatory experience for Bolt, as he vowed never again to let himself be affected by pre-race nerves.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-38)  As a member of the Jamaican  [sprint relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sprint_relay "Sprint relay")  team, he also took two silver medals and set national junior records in the  [4×100 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_100_metres_relay "4 × 100 metres relay")  and  [4×400 metres relay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_400_metres_relay "4 × 400 metres relay"), running times of 39.15 s and 3:04.06 minutes respectively.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-39)[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-40)

The rush of medals continued as he won four golds at the  [2003 CARIFTA Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_CARIFTA_Games "2003 CARIFTA Games")  and was awarded the  [Austin Sealy Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CARIFTA_Games#Austin_Sealy_Award_Winners "CARIFTA Games")  for the most outstanding athlete of the games.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-carifta1-41)[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-carifta2-42)[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-43)  He won another gold at the  [2003 World Youth Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Youth_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Youth Championships in Athletics"). He set a new championship record in the 200 m with a time of 20.40 s, despite a 1.1  [m/s](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metre_per_second "Metre per second")  [head wind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_m#Climatic_conditions "100 m").[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-44)  [Michael Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Johnson_(athlete) "Michael Johnson (athlete)"), the 200 m world-record holder, took note of Bolt's potential but worried that the young sprinter might be over-pressured, stating, "It's all about what he does three, four, five years down the line".[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Thunder-45)  Bolt had also impressed the athletics hierarchy, and he received the  [IAAF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF "IAAF")  Rising Star Award for 2002.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Beyond-46)

Bolt competed in his final Jamaican High School Championships in 2003. He broke the 200 m and 400 m records with times of 20.25 s and 45.35 s, respectively. Bolt's runs were a significant improvement upon the previous records, beating the 200 m best by more than half a second and the 400 m record by almost a second.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  While Bolt improved upon the 200 m time three months later, setting the still-standing  [World youth best](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_youth_bests_in_athletics "List of world youth bests in athletics")  at the  [2003 Pan American Junior Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_Pan_American_Junior_Championships "2003 Pan American Junior Championships").[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-47)  The 400 m time remains No. 6 on the all-time youth list, surpassed only once since, by future Olympic champion  [Kirani James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirani_James "Kirani James").[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-48)

Bolt turned his main focus to the 200 m and equalled  [Roy Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Martin_(sprinter) "Roy Martin (sprinter)")'s  [world junior record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_junior_records_in_athletics "List of world junior records in athletics")  of 20.13 s at the Pan-American Junior Championships.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-49)  This performance attracted interest from the press, and his times in the 200 m and 400 m led to him being touted as a possible successor to Johnson. Indeed, at sixteen years old, Bolt had reached times that Johnson did not register until he was twenty, and Bolt's 200 m time was superior to  [Maurice Greene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Greene_(athlete) "Maurice Greene (athlete)")'s season's best that year.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Thunder-45)

Bolt was growing more popular in his homeland. Howard Hamilton, who was given the task of Public Defender by the government, urged the JAAA to nurture him and prevent  [burnout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnout_(psychology) "Burnout (psychology)"), calling Bolt "the most phenomenal sprinter ever produced by this island".[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Thunder-45)  His popularity and the attractions of the capital city were beginning to be a burden to the young sprinter. Bolt was increasingly unfocused on his athletic career and preferred to eat fast food, play basketball, and party in Kingston's club scene. In the absence of a disciplined lifestyle, he became ever-more reliant on his natural ability to beat his competitors on the track.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-50)

As the reigning 200 m champion at both the World Youth and World Junior championships, Bolt hoped to take a clean sweep of the world 200 m championships in the  [Senior World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Championships in Athletics")  in Paris.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  He beat all comers at the 200 m in the World Championship trials. Bolt was pragmatic about his chances and noted that, even if he did not make the final, he would consider setting a personal best a success.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Thunder-45)[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-WC03-51)  However, he suffered a bout of  [conjunctivitis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunctivitis "Conjunctivitis")  before the event, and it ruined his training schedule.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  Realising that he would not be in peak condition, the JAAA refused to let him participate in the finals, on the grounds that he was too young and inexperienced. Bolt was dismayed at missing out on the opportunity, but focused on getting himself in shape to gain a place on the Jamaican Olympic team instead.[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-WC03-51)  Even though he missed the World Championships, Bolt was awarded the IAAF Rising Star Award for the 2003 season on the strength of his junior record-equalling run.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Beyond-46)[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-52)
## Personal life

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Usain_Bolt_2011_World_Athletics_Gala.jpg/220px-Usain_Bolt_2011_World_Athletics_Gala.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Usain_Bolt_2011_World_Athletics_Gala.jpg)

Bolt with the IAAF men's  [Athlete of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Athlete_of_the_Year "IAAF World Athlete of the Year")  award in  [Monaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monaco "Monaco")

Bolt expresses a love for dancing and his character is frequently described as laid-back and relaxed.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-BBC10-27)[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-258)  His Jamaican track and field idols include  [Herb McKenley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herb_McKenley "Herb McKenley")  and former Jamaican 100 m and 200 m world record holder,  [Don Quarrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Quarrie "Don Quarrie").  [Michael Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Johnson_(sprinter) "Michael Johnson (sprinter)"), the former 200 m world and Olympic record holder, is also held in high esteem by Bolt.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-BBC10-27)

Bolt has the nickname "Lightning Bolt" due to his name and speed.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Focus-1)  He is  [Catholic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism")  and known for making the  [sign of the cross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sign_of_the_cross "Sign of the cross")  before racing competitively, and he wears a  [Miraculous Medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miraculous_Medal "Miraculous Medal")  during his races. His middle name is St. Leo.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-catholicnewsagency1-259)

In 2010, Bolt also revealed his fondness of music, when he played a  [reggae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reggae "Reggae")  DJ set to a crowd in Paris.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-260)  He is also an avid fan of the  _[Call of Duty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty "Call of Duty")_  video game series, saying, "I stay up late [playing the game online], I can't help it."[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-261)

In his autobiography, Bolt reveals that he has suffered from  [scoliosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scoliosis "Scoliosis"), a condition that has curved his spine to the right and has made his right leg half an inch shorter than his left.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-262)  A result of this is that his left leg remains on the ground 14 percent longer than his right leg, with left leg striking with 955 lbs of force and right with 1080 lbs. Biomechanics researchers have studied, with no firm conclusions, whether this asymmetry has helped or hurt Bolt in his sprinting career.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-263)

He popularised the "lightning bolt" pose, also known as "to di world" or "bolting", which he used both before races and in celebration. The pose consists of extending a slightly raised left arm to the side and the right arm folded across the chest, with both hands have the thumb and  [index finger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_finger "Index finger")  outstretched. His performance of the pose during his Olympic and World Championship victories led to widespread copying of the move, from American President  [Barack Obama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")  to small children. It has been suggested that the pose comes from Jamaican  [dancehall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dancehall "Dancehall")  moves of the period,[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-264)[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-265)  though Olympic sprint champion  [Bernard Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Williams_(sprinter) "Bernard Williams (sprinter)")  also had performed similar celebration moves earlier that decade.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-266)

### Other sports

[Cricket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket "Cricket")  was the first sport to interest Bolt, and he said if he were not a sprinter, he would be a  [fast bowler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_bowling "Fast bowling")  instead.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-BBC10-27)  As a child, he was a supporter of the  [Pakistani cricket team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team "Pakistan national cricket team")  and admired the bowling of  [Waqar Younis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waqar_Younis "Waqar Younis").[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-267)  He is also a fan of  [Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_national_cricket_team "India national cricket team")  batsman  [Sachin Tendulkar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar "Sachin Tendulkar"),  [West Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Indies_cricket_team "West Indies cricket team")  opener  [Chris Gayle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Gayle "Chris Gayle"),[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-268)  and  [Australian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team "Australia national cricket team")  opener  [Matthew Hayden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Hayden "Matthew Hayden").[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-269)  During a charity cricket match, Bolt  [clean-bowled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowled "Bowled")  Gayle who was complimentary of Bolt's pace and swing.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-270)  Bolt also struck a  [six](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boundary_(cricket) "Boundary (cricket)")  off Gayle's bowling. Another bowler complimentary of Bolt's pace was former West Indies fast-bowling great  [Curtly Ambrose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtly_Ambrose "Curtly Ambrose").[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-271)

After talking with Australian cricketer  [Shane Warne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shane_Warne "Shane Warne"), Bolt suggested that if he were able to get time off he would be interested in playing in the cricket  [Big Bash League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Bash_League "Big Bash League").  [Melbourne Stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne_Stars "Melbourne Stars")  chief executive Clint Cooper said there were free spots on his team should be available. Bolt stated that he enjoyed the  [Twenty20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty20 "Twenty20")  version of the game, admiring the aggressive and constant nature of the batting. On his own ability, he said "I don't know how good I am. I will probably have to get a lot of practice in."[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-272)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-273)

Bolt is also a fan of  [Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League")  football team  [Manchester United](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.").[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-english.rfi.fr-274)  He has declared he is a fan of  [Dutch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people")  striker  [Ruud van Nistelrooy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruud_van_Nistelrooy "Ruud van Nistelrooy").[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-275)  Bolt was a special guest of Manchester United at the  [2011 UEFA Champions League Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2011 UEFA Champions League Final")  in London, where he stated that he would like to play for them after his retirement.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-276)

In 2013, Bolt played basketball in the  [NBA All-Star Weekend Celebrity Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_All-Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Game "NBA All-Star Weekend Celebrity Game"). He scored two points from a  [slam dunk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slam_dunk "Slam dunk")  but acknowledged his other basketball skills were lacking.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-277)

### Biographical film

A biographical film based on the athletic life of Bolt to win three Olympic gold medals, titled  _[I Am Bolt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Am_Bolt "I Am Bolt")_, was released on 28 November 2016 in United Kingdom. The film was directed by Benjamin Turner and Gabe Turner.[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-278)[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-279)

## Sponsorships and advertising work

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Usain_Bolt_2012_Olympics_3.jpg/220px-Usain_Bolt_2012_Olympics_3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Usain_Bolt_2012_Olympics_3.jpg)

Bolt wearing  [Puma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puma_AG "Puma AG")  shoes as part of a sponsorship deal.

After winning the 200 m title in the  [2002 World Junior Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_World_Junior_Championships_in_Athletics "2002 World Junior Championships in Athletics")  in Kingston, Bolt signed a sponsorship deal with  [Puma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puma_AG "Puma AG").[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-280)  To promote Bolt's chase for Olympic glory in the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in Beijing, China, Puma released a series of videos including Bolt's then-world-record-setting run in  [Icahn Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icahn_Stadium "Icahn Stadium")  and his Olympic preparations.[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-281)  After his world record breaking run in New York City, which was preceded by a  [lightning storm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm"),[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Storm-282)  the press frequently made puns on the Jamaican's name, nicknaming him "Lightning Bolt" and the "[Bolt from the blue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolt_from_the_blue "Bolt from the blue")".[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-283)[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-284)[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-285)  During the 2008 Beijing 100 m final, Bolt wore golden Puma Complete Theseus spikes that had "Beijing 100 m Gold" emblazoned across them.[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-286)  Writing of Bolt's performance at the Olympics,  _[The Associated Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Associated_Press "The Associated Press")_  said:

> Almost single-handedly, Bolt has helped track transform itself from a dying sport to one with a singular, smiling, worldwide star.
> 
> — _[The Associated Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Associated_Press "The Associated Press")_, 10 August 2012[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Newsday-190)

In September 2010, Bolt travelled to Australia where his sponsor  [Gatorade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gatorade "Gatorade")  was holding an event called the "Gatorade Bolt" to find Australia's fastest footballer. The event was held at the  [Sydney International Athletic Centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney_International_Athletic_Centre "Sydney International Athletic Centre")  and featured football players from  [rugby league](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league"),  [rugby union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union"),  [Australian rules football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_rules_football "Australian rules football"), and  [association football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football "Association football"). Prior to the race Bolt gave the runners some private coaching and also participated in the 10th anniversary celebrations for the  [2000 Summer Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympic_Games "2000 Summer Olympic Games").[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-287)

In January 2012, Bolt impersonated  [Richard Branson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Branson "Richard Branson")  in an advertising campaign for  [Virgin Media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Media "Virgin Media").[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-Usain_Bolt_mimics_Richard_Branson_in_Virgin_Media_superfast_broadband_ad-288)  The campaign was directed by  [Seth Gordon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seth_Gordon "Seth Gordon")  and features the  [Virgin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Group "Virgin Group")  founder Branson to promote its broadband service. In March 2012, Bolt starred in an advert for Visa and the 2012 Summer Olympics.[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-289)  In July 2012, Bolt and  [RockLive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RockLive "RockLive")  launched  _Bolt!_, an  [Apple iOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS_(Apple) "IOS (Apple)")  game based on his exploits.  _Bolt!_  quickly became the No. 1 app in Jamaica and climbed the UK  [iTunes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITunes "ITunes")  charts to reach No. 2 on the list of Top Free Apps.[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-290)

Bolt's autobiography,  _My Story: 9.58: Being the World's Fastest Man_, was released in 2010. Bolt had previously said that the book "...should be exciting, it's my life, and I'm a cool and exciting guy."[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-english.rfi.fr-274)  His athletics agent is  [PACE Sports Management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PACE_Sports_Management "PACE Sports Management").[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-291)

As part of his sponsorship deal with Puma, the manufacturer sends sporting equipment to his alma mater, William Knibb Memorial High School, every year. At Bolt's insistence, advertisements featuring him are filmed in Jamaica, by a Jamaican production crew, in an attempt to boost local enterprise and gain exposure for the country.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-292)  In 2017, Bolt had the third highest earning social media income for sponsors among sportspeople (behind  [Cristiano Ronaldo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo "Cristiano Ronaldo")  and  [Neymar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neymar "Neymar")), and he was the only non-footballer in the top seven.[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usain_Bolt#cite_note-293)

name: Javier
bio:
**Francisco Javier Gómez Noya**  (born 25 March 1983) is a  [Spanish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_people "Spanish people")  [triathlete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon "Triathlon"). He is the winner of five  [ITU Triathlon World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITU_Triathlon_World_Championships "ITU Triathlon World Championships"), he holds three  [ITU Triathlon World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITU_Triathlon_World_Cup "ITU Triathlon World Cup")  titles, and won the Silver medal for Spain at the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics")  in  [men's triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s "Triathlon at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's"). He has also won world titles for  [Ironman 70.3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ironman_70.3 "Ironman 70.3")  and  [XTERRA Triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XTERRA_Triathlon "XTERRA Triathlon").

Born to Spanish immigrants (both from  [Galicia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galicia_(Spain) "Galicia (Spain)")) in  [Basel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel "Basel"),  [Switzerland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland"), he returned to Spain and now lives in  [Pontevedra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontevedra "Pontevedra"),  [Galicia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galicia_(Spain) "Galicia (Spain)").

## Athletic career

Gómez took up triathlon at the age of 15 after previously playing football and competing in swimming. However his career suffered a setback in 2000 when a routine medical test by the  [Consejo Superior de Deportes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consejo_Superior_de_Deportes "Consejo Superior de Deportes")  (CSD) revealed an "abnormal heart valve", leading to a six-year battle between Gómez and the Spanish sporting authorities regarding his right to compete internationally.
