He initially won this right in November 2003, but he was not selected for the  [2004 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics")  and in 2005 the CSD banned him from international and domestic competition until February 2006.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-1)

In the nine years from 2002 to 2010, Gómez took part in 57 ITU competitions and achieved 54 top ten positions, among which are 23 first-place finishes. In 2003 and in 2008, Gómez was ITU Triathlon World Champion (both under-23 and Elite categories respectively in 2003). In 2007 and 2009 he was the Elite European Champion. He finished second in the World Championships in 2007 and was the runner up in  [2011 ITU Sprint Distance Triathlon World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_ITU_Sprint_Distance_Triathlon_World_Championships "2011 ITU Sprint Distance Triathlon World Championships").

At the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in  [men's triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s "Triathlon at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's")  Gómez was among the pre-race favourites to win. With 300 meters to go in that race,  [Jan Frodeno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Frodeno "Jan Frodeno")  was the leader of a group made up of Gómez, Athens 2004 Silver medalist  [Bevan Docherty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bevan_Docherty "Bevan Docherty")  of New Zealand, and Sydney 2000 Gold medalist  [Simon Whitfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield "Simon Whitfield")  of Canada. Whitfield opened up the gap with a sprint with only Frodeno responding. Frodeno sprinted away with 50 meters from the finish to claim the gold medal.  [Simon Whitfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Whitfield "Simon Whitfield")  took the silver medal five seconds behind, and New Zealand's  [Bevan Docherty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bevan_Docherty "Bevan Docherty")  won the bronze medal 12 seconds back. Gómez placed 4th, 20.64 seconds behind Frodeno.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-Sportsref-2)

In 2010, Gómez was the number one in the World Championship Series ranking, in 2009 he was second, his only rivals being the Brownlee brothers  [Alistair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alistair_Brownlee "Alistair Brownlee")  and  [Jonathan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Brownlee "Jonathan Brownlee"), with whom he represents  [ECS Triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECS_Triathlon "ECS Triathlon")  in the French Club Championship Series  _[Lyonnaise des Eaux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Prix_de_Triathlon "Grand Prix de Triathlon")_. At the  [2010 ITU Triathlon World Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_ITU_Triathlon_World_Championship "2010 ITU Triathlon World Championship")  final in  [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest "Budapest"), Gómez came second to British triathlete  [Alistair Brownlee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alistair_Brownlee "Alistair Brownlee"), but despite the loss in the final, he won the Championship overall.

At the London Summer Olympics in 2012, Gómez took the Silver medal in men's triathlon, 11 seconds behind Gold medalist Alistair Brownlee.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-Sportsref-2)  Following the Olympic games Gómez won the  [Hy-Vee Triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hy-Vee_Triathlon "Hy-Vee Triathlon")  against a highly competitive field. A month later in his first ever cross triathlon race, he won the  [2012 XTERRA World Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XTERRA_Triathlon "XTERRA Triathlon").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-3)

In 2013, Gómez continued his success from last year winning the  [Escape from Alcatraz Triathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escape_from_Alcatraz_(triathlon) "Escape from Alcatraz (triathlon)")[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-4)  and repeating as the Hy-Vee Triathlon winner. He would then go on to win the  [2013 ITU World Triathlon Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_ITU_World_Triathlon_Series "2013 ITU World Triathlon Series"), his third such title. With this world championship he joined  [Peter Robertson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Robertson_(triathlete) "Peter Robertson (triathlete)")  as the other triathlete with three titles to his name, and is just shy of  [Simon Lessing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Lessing "Simon Lessing")  who has four world titles.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-5)  Later that year Gómez competed in his first middle distance race by taking first at the Challenge Half Barcelona race.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-6)  In February 2014 he raced and won his second middle distance race,  [Ironman 70.3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ironman_70.3 "Ironman 70.3")  Panama.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-7)

In 2014, Gómez won his fourth ITU World Championships, winning four out of the eight possible races as well as placing third at the Grand Final, tying him for all time championships with Simon Lessing. Gómez also won the  [2014 Ironman 70.3 World Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Ironman_70.3_World_Championship "2014 Ironman 70.3 World Championship"). The next year, Gómez took his third consecutive ITU World Championship, and his fifth title overall, by finishing second at the Triathlon World Series Grand Final in Chicago.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-8)

In 2019, Gómez won his first full Ironman distance race at Ironman Malaysia with a course record of 8:18:59. He received a qualification slot to the  [2020 Ironman World Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2020_Ironman_World_Championship&action=edit&redlink=1 "2020 Ironman World Championship (page does not exist)").  [[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-9)[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Javier_G%C3%B3mez_Noya#cite_note-10)

name: Sarah
bio:
**Sarah Walker**  [OLY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OLY "OLY")  (born 10 July 1988) is a New Zealand  [BMX racer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMX_racing "BMX racing")  of  [Māori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people "Māori people")  and European descent. A competitor at the  [2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  and  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics"), she won silver in the  [Women's BMX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the latter event. Missing out on selection for the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  due to injury, she was elected onto the  [IOC Athletes' Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOC_Athletes%27_Commission "IOC Athletes' Commission")  during those Games.

## Private life

Walker was born in  [Whakatane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whakatane "Whakatane")  in the Bay of Plenty, and grew up in nearby  [Kawerau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kawerau "Kawerau").[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Kawerau-2)  Of Māori descent,[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-3)  she attended Kawerau South School[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Kawerau-2)  and  [Trident High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trident_High_School "Trident High School")  in Whakatane.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-4)

## BMX career

Walker took up BMX due to sibling rivalry; she wanted to be able to do what her younger brother could do, and do it better than him.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  In the 2008 season  [UCI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Cycliste_Internationale "Union Cycliste Internationale")  Rounds, Walker won seven races, came second in one race and didn't race two races. She was ranked number one in the world by the UCI in 2008,[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-6)  and was one of the favourites to win the  [BMX women's event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in  [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), in the end she finished fourth.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  Walker has won a total of twelve New Zealand 20" titles from 1999 to 2011.

On 25 July 2009, Walker won the BMX World Championship in  [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), Australia in both the Elite Women and the Elite Cruiser Women events.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Stuff.co.nz_2674158-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-NZ_Herald_10586844-8)

At the 2010 BMX World Championship in  [Pietermaritzburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietermaritzburg "Pietermaritzburg"),  [South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), Walker finished second in the Elite Women's event, with first place going to  [Shanaze Reade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanaze_Reade "Shanaze Reade"). A crash during the Elite Cruiser event meant that Walker was not able hold on to her 2009 championship title.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Stuff.co.nz_3979377-9)

In 2011, Walker made the podium in three out of four World Cup events to win the overall World Cup title, winning the Papendal Supercross in the Netherlands, second at the Test Event in London and third in South Africa. The fourth event was in USA where she finished sixth.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

At the 2012 Supercross in Norway, Walker dislocated her shoulder, which almost put her out of contention for the Olympics in London. After six weeks, she had to qualify for the Olympics at the World Championships in  [Birmingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham"), England where she did so with a fifth place in the semi final.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-10)

At the September  [2014 UCI BMX Supercross World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_UCI_BMX_Supercross_World_Cup "2014 UCI BMX Supercross World Cup")  race in California, Walker had a fall and suffered a serious head injury.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-11)  Whilst her helmet cam recorded her calmly giving detailed accounts to medical staff of what happened to her, she has no recollection of the entire day. She had daily headaches for the next six weeks, and it was five months before she received medical clearance.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  As of February 2016, Walker has experienced a total of 15 fractures during her BMX career.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-12)

As well as competing in BMX events around the world, Walker has also been the marketing face for Beef + Lamb New Zealand since 2008.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-13)  She is a sponsored rider for  [Avanti Bikes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avanti_(bicycle_manufacturer) "Avanti (bicycle manufacturer)"), using their line of ABD BMX bikes when racing.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Avanti_profile-1)

### Olympic career

Walker wanted to become an Olympic athlete ever since watching New Zealand swimmer  [Danyon Loader](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danyon_Loader "Danyon Loader")  receiving his gold medals at the  [1996 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_at_the_1996_Summer_Olympics "Swimming at the 1996 Summer Olympics").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  She was about to start track cycling and quit BMX when it was announced as an Olympic sport for the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in  [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"),[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  and this was the first Games she attended, competing in the  [women's BMX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX"). In the medals race, she ran a time of 38.805, finishing fourth. In the same  [event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics")  she got a silver medal, with a time of 38.644.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  She missed being nominated for the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  in  [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro")  due to breaking her arm during training in February 2016.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  During the Rio Games, it was announced that she had been elected onto the  [IOC Athletes' Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOC_Athletes%27_Commission "IOC Athletes' Commission"); whilst initially missing out to  [Yelena Isinbayeva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelena_Isinbayeva "Yelena Isinbayeva"),  [president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_International_Olympic_Committee "President of the International Olympic Committee")  [Thomas Bach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Bach "Thomas Bach")  proposed that Walker be added to the group.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-14)

## Sponsorship and advertising work

Walker is an ambassador for Beef and Lamb New Zealand, alongside other athlete ambassadors  [Lisa Carrington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Carrington "Lisa Carrington"),  [Eliza McCartney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliza_McCartney "Eliza McCartney")  and  [Sophie Pascoe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Pascoe "Sophie Pascoe").[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-15)

name: Carl
bio:
**Frederick Carlton**  "**Carl**"  **Lewis**  (born July 1, 1961) is an American former  [track and field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field")  athlete who won nine  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")  [gold medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_medal "Gold medal"), one Olympic silver medal, and 10  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "IAAF World Championships in Athletics")  medals, including eight gold. His career spanned from 1979 to 1996, when he last won an Olympic event. He is one of only three Olympic athletes who won a gold medal in the same individual event in four consecutive Olympic Games.

Lewis was a dominant sprinter and long jumper who topped the world rankings in the  [100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_meters "100 meters"),  [200 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_meters "200 meters")  and  [long jump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_jump "Long jump")  events frequently from 1981 to the early 1990s. He set  [world records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_athletics "List of world records in athletics")  in the 100 m,  [4 × 100 m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_100_meters_relay "4 × 100 meters relay")  and  [4 × 200 m relays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4_%C3%97_200_meters_relay "4 × 200 meters relay"), while his  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_records_in_athletics#Indoor_world_records "World records in athletics")  in the indoor long jump has stood since 1984. His 65 consecutive victories in the long jump achieved over a span of 10 years is one of the sport's longest undefeated streaks. Over the course of his athletics career, Lewis broke ten seconds for the 100 meters 15 times and 20 seconds for the 200 meters 10 times. Lewis also long jumped over 28 feet 71 times.

His accomplishments have led to numerous accolades, including being voted "World Athlete of the Century" by the  [International Association of Athletics Federations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_of_Athletics_Federations "International Association of Athletics Federations")  and "Sportsman of the Century" by the  [International Olympic Committee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee"), "Olympian of the Century" by  _[Sports Illustrated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_  and "Athlete of the Year" by  _[Track & Field News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%26_Field_News "Track & Field News")_  in 1982, 1983, and 1984.

After retiring from his athletics career, Lewis became an actor and has appeared in a number of films. In 2011, he attempted to run for a seat as a  [Democrat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Democratic Party (United States)")  in the  [New Jersey Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Jersey_Senate "New Jersey Senate"), but was removed from the ballot due to the state's residency requirement. Lewis owns a marketing and branding company named C.L.E.G., which markets and brands products and services including his own.

## Athletic career
### Fame as a competitive athlete[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carl_Lewis&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro "Edit section: Fame as a competitive athlete")]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Carl_Lewis_as_a_University_of_Houston_athlete.jpg/220px-Carl_Lewis_as_a_University_of_Houston_athlete.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carl_Lewis_as_a_University_of_Houston_athlete.jpg)

Lewis performing the long jump at the  [University of Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Houston "University of Houston")

Frederick Carlton Lewis was born in  [Birmingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham,_Alabama "Birmingham, Alabama"), Alabama, on July 1, 1961, the son of William Lewis (1927–1987)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-2)  and  [Evelyn née Lawler Lewis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Lawler "Evelyn Lawler"). His mother was a hurdler on the 1951 Pan-Am team.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-TFNInterview-3)  His older brother  [Cleveland Lewis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Lewis "Cleveland Lewis")  played professional soccer for the  [Memphis Rogues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memphis_Rogues "Memphis Rogues").[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-4)  His parents ran a local athletics club that provided a crucial influence on both Carl and his sister  [Carol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carol_Lewis "Carol Lewis").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-dadobit-5)  She became an elite long jumper, finishing 9th at the 1984 Olympics and taking bronze at the 1983 World Championships.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-6)

Lewis was initially coached by his father, who also coached other local athletes to elite status.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-dadobit-5)  At age 13, Lewis began competing in the long jump, and he emerged as a promising athlete while coached by Andy Dudek and Paul Minore at  [Willingboro High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willingboro_High_School "Willingboro High School")  in his hometown of  [Willingboro Township, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willingboro_Township,_New_Jersey "Willingboro Township, New Jersey").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-TFNInterview-3)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-7)  He achieved the ranking of fourth on the all-time World Junior list of long jumpers.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-TFNInterview-3)

Many colleges tried to recruit Lewis, and he chose to enroll at the  [University of Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Houston "University of Houston")  where Tom Tellez was coach. Tellez would thereafter remain Lewis's coach for his entire career. Days after graduating from high school in 1979, Lewis broke the high school long jump record with a leap of 8.13 m (26 ft 8 in).[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-8)  By the end of 1979, Lewis was ranked fifth in the world for the long jump, according to  _Track and Field News_.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-ljworldrank-9)

An old knee injury had flared up again at the end of the high school year, and this might have had consequences on his fitness. Lewis worked with Tellez and adapted his technique so that he was able to jump without pain, and he went on to win the 1980  [National Collegiate Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association")  (NCAA) title with a wind-assisted jump of 8.35 m (27 ft  4  1⁄2 in).[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-TFNInterview-3)

Though his focus was on the long jump, he was now starting to emerge as a talent in the sprints. Comparisons were beginning to be made with  [Jesse Owens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_Owens "Jesse Owens"), who dominated sprint and long jump events in the 1930s. Lewis qualified for the American team for the  [1980 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics")  in the long jump and as a member of the 4 × 100 m relay team.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-TFNInterview-3)  The  [Olympic boycott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics_boycott "1980 Summer Olympics boycott")  precluded Lewis from competing in Moscow; he instead participated in the  [Liberty Bell Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_Bell_Classic "Liberty Bell Classic")  in July 1980, which was an alternate meet for boycotting nations. He jumped 7.77 m (25 ft  5  3⁄4 in) for a bronze medal, and the American 4 × 100 m relay team won gold with a time of 38.61 s.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-10)  Lewis received one of 461  [Congressional Gold Medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Congressional_Gold_Medal_recipients "List of Congressional Gold Medal recipients")  created especially for the athletes precluded from competing in the 1980 Olympics.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-11)  At year's end, Lewis was ranked 6th in the world in the long jump and 7th in the 100 m.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-ljworldrank-9)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-100worldrank-12)

### Breakthrough in 1981 and 1982

At the start of 1981, Lewis's best legal long jump was his high school record from 1979. On June 20, Lewis improved his personal best by almost half a meter by leaping 8.62 m (28 ft  3  1⁄4 in) at the  [TAC Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Outdoor_Track_and_Field_Championships "USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships")  while still a teenager.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-13)

While marks set at the thinner air of high altitude are eligible for world records,[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-altitude-14)  Lewis was determined to set his records at sea level. In response to a question about his skipping a 1982 long jump competition at altitude, he said, "I want the record and I plan to get it, but not at altitude. I don't want that '(A)' [for altitude] after the mark."[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-15)  When he gained prominence in the early 1980s, all the extant men's 100 m and 200 m records and the long jump record had been set at the  [high altitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_in_athletics#Altitude "1968 in athletics")  of  [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City").[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-altitude-14)

Also in 1981, Lewis became the fastest 100 m sprinter in the world. His relatively modest best from 1979 (10.67 s) improved to a world-class 10.21 the next year. But 1981 saw him run 10.00 s at the Southwest Conference Championships in Dallas on May 16, a time that was the third-fastest in history and stood as the low-altitude record.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-16)  For the first time, Lewis was ranked number one in the world, in both the 100 m and the long jump. He won his first national titles in the 100 m and long jump. Additionally, he won the  [James E. Sullivan Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_E._Sullivan_Award "James E. Sullivan Award")  as the top amateur athlete in the United States.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-17)

In 1982, Lewis continued his dominance, and for the first time it seemed someone might challenge  [Bob Beamon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Beamon "Bob Beamon")'s world record of 8.90 m (29 ft  2  1⁄4 in) in the long jump set at the  [1968 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics "1968 Summer Olympics"), a mark often described as one of the greatest athletic achievements ever.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-18)  Before Lewis, 28 ft 0 in (8.53 m) had been exceeded on two occasions by two people: Beamon and  [1980 Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics")  champion  [Lutz Dombrowski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lutz_Dombrowski "Lutz Dombrowski"). During 1982, Lewis cleared 28 ft 0 in (8.53 m) five times outdoors, twice more indoors, going as far as 8.7 m (28 ft  6  1⁄2 in) at Indianapolis on July 24.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-19)  He also ran 10.00 s in the 100 m, the world's fastest time, matching his low-altitude record from 1981. He achieved his 10.00 s clocking the same weekend he leapt 8.61 m (28 ft  2  3⁄4 in) twice, and the day he recorded his new low-altitude record 8.76 m (28 ft  8  3⁄4 in) at  [Indianapolis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis "Indianapolis"), he had three fouls with his toe barely over the board, two of which seemed to exceed Beamon's record, the third which several observers said reached 30 ft 0 in (9.14 m). Lewis said he should have been credited with that jump, claiming the track officials misinterpreted the rules on fouls.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-20)

He repeated his number one ranking in the 100 m and long jump, and ranked number six in the 200 m. Additionally, he was named Athlete of the Year by  _Track and Field News_. From 1981 until 1992, Lewis topped the 100 m ranking six times (seven if  [Ben Johnson's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Johnson_(Canadian_sprinter) "Ben Johnson (Canadian sprinter)")  1987 top ranking is ignored), and ranked no lower than third.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-100worldrank-12)  His dominance in the long jump was even greater, as he topped the rankings nine times during the same period, and ranked second in the other years.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-ljworldrank-9)

### 1983 and the inaugural World Championships

The  [International Association of Athletics Federations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_of_Athletics_Federations "International Association of Athletics Federations")  (IAAF), the governing body of track and field, organized the first  [World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "IAAF World Championships in Athletics")  in 1983. Lewis's chief rival in the long jump was predicted to be the man who last beat him: Larry Myricks. But though Myricks had joined Lewis in surpassing 28 ft 0 in (8.53 m) the year before, he failed to qualify for the American team, and Lewis won at Helsinki with relative ease. His winning leap of 8.55 m (28 ft  1⁄2 in) defeated silver medalist Jason Grimes by 0.26 m (10 in).[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-21)

He also won the 100 m with relative ease. There,  [Calvin Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Smith "Calvin Smith")  who had earlier that year set a new world record in the 100 m at altitude with a 9.93 s performance, was soundly beaten by Lewis 10.07 s to 10.21 s.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-22)  Smith won the 200 m title,[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-23)  an event which Lewis had not entered, but even there he was partly in Lewis's shadow as Lewis had set an American record in that event earlier that year. He won the 200 m on June 19 at the TAC/Mobil Championships in 19.75 s, the second-fastest time in history and the low-altitude record, only 0.03 s behind  [Pietro Mennea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietro_Mennea "Pietro Mennea")'s 1979 mark. Observers here noted that Lewis probably could have broken the world record if he did not ease off in the final meters to raise his arms in celebration.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-Field_News'_1983,_p.4,_9-24)[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-25)  Finally, Lewis ran the  [anchor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_leg "Anchor leg")  in the 4 × 100 m relay, winning in 37.86 s, a new world record and the first in Lewis's career.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-26)

Lewis's year-best performances in the 100 m and long jump were not at the World Championships, but at other meets. He became the first person to run a sub-10 second 100 m at low-altitude with a 9.97 s in  [Modesto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modesto,_California "Modesto, California")  on May 14.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-27)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-28)  His gold at the World Championships and his other fast times earned him the number one ranking in the world that year, despite Calvin Smith's world record. At the TAC Championships on June 19, he set a new low-altitude record in the long jump, 8.79 m (28 ft 10 in)[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-Field_News'_1983,_p.4,_9-24)  and earned the world number one ranking in that event.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-29)  _Track and Field News_  ranked him number two in the 200 m, despite his low-altitude record of 19.75 s, behind Smith, who had won gold at Helsinki.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-200mranking-30)  Lewis was again named Athlete of the Year by the magazine.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Lewis#cite_note-AOTY-31)

name: Joaquim
bio:
**Joaquim Carvalho Cruz**  (born March 12, 1963) is a former  [Brazilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil "Brazil")  middle-distance runner, winner of the 800 meters at the  [1984 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_Summer_Olympics "1984 Summer Olympics"). He is one of only five men to run the  [800 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/800_metres "800 metres")  in less than 1 minute, 42 seconds.

## Biography

Cruz was born in  [Taguatinga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taguatinga,_Federal_District "Taguatinga, Federal District"),  [Distrito Federal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil) "Federal District (Brazil)"). As the son of a steel worker, he began running as a 13-year-old, and soon showed astonishing talent as a junior. At the age of only 15 his personal best over 800 m stood at 1:51 min. After setting a junior  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record "World record")  of 1:44.3 min in 1981, he received a scholarship for the  [University of Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Oregon "University of Oregon")  in 1983. The move immediately paid off, and Cruz won the  [NCAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association")  championships over 800 m that same year. He also competed in the  [inaugural World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1983 World Championships in Athletics")  in 1983, winning the bronze.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-iaaf-2)

The following year, Cruz became one of only a handful of people to win the 800/1500 m double at the 1984 NCAA Track & Field Championships (a feat that would not be repeated for another 26 years until another Oregon Duck,  [Andrew Wheating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Wheating "Andrew Wheating"), turned the trick in 2010). Cruz is the co-holder of  [University of Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Oregon "University of Oregon")  1,500 m school record of 3:36.48 along with A.J. Acosta.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-3)  Later that summer, he ran a time of 2:14.09 min over 1000 m in  [Nice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nice "Nice")  which is still the current  [South American record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_South_American_records_in_athletics "List of South American records in athletics")  over that distance.

The 1984 Olympic Games were held in  [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), and Cruz was considered to be one of the 800 m favorites, along with  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record "World record")  holder  [Sebastian Coe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sebastian_Coe "Sebastian Coe")  of Britain. In the last turn of the 800 meter final, Cruz started a sprint from second place and took the lead, never losing it. He crossed the line in 1:43.00, breaking  [Alberto Juantorena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberto_Juantorena "Alberto Juantorena")'s Olympic Record and making him the first Brazilian Olympic track and field gold medalist since  [triple jumper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_jump "Triple jump")  [Adhemar Ferreira da Silva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adhemar_Ferreira_da_Silva "Adhemar Ferreira da Silva")  won both in  [1952](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 1952 Summer Olympics")  and  [1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

Later that week, after winning his first round heat of the Olympic 1500 m, Cruz, due to a cold, did not start in the semi-finals, which caused quite a stir among the Brazilians, who thought he didn't want to represent his country in an event in which his chances of winning were smaller. Cruz eventually recovered from his cold and had a remarkable five-day stretch of racing a few weeks after the Olympic Games. First, he ran a new Brazilian 800 m record of 1:42.34 at the Weltklasse meet in Zurich, becoming only the second runner in history to break 1:43. Two days later he ran a 1:42.41 at the  [Memorial Van Damme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Van_Damme "Memorial Van Damme")  meet in  [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), and then two days after that, at a meeting in  [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), Cruz ran the second fastest 800 meters in history, his time of 1:41.77 was only four hundredths of a second outside of Coe's world record. He is the fifth fastest athlete in the history of the event.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-4)  By the end of the year, he was the NCAA champion, the Olympic champion, undefeated in all seven of his 800-meter finals, had run the 2nd, 4th, 5th, and 6th fastest 800 meter times in history, and easily ranked as #1 in the world for 800 meters in 1984 by  [Track & Field News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%26_Field_News "Track & Field News")  magazine.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

In 1985 Cruz confirmed the excellent results of the previous year by winning six of his eight 800 meter races, the last three of which were won under 1:43: 1:42.98 at ISTAF, 1:42.53 in Cologne (beating Sebastian Coe), and 1:42.49 in Koblenz. His record was good enough to earn him a World #1 ranking by  _Track & Field News_  magazine for the second year in a row. He also ran the world's 3rd fastest 1,000 meter time for 1985, a 2:15.11. In the following two years he struggled with injuries and raced little, though he did manage to win the gold medal in the 1,500 meters at the  [1987 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_Pan_American_Games "1987 Pan American Games"), defeating both  [Jim Spivey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Spivey "Jim Spivey")  (who within the next month would win a bronze medal at the World Championships) and American mile record holder  [Steve Scott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Scott_(athlete) "Steve Scott (athlete)").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

At the  [1988 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics"), Cruz appeared to be on his way to retain his Olympic 800 m title when he was passed by  [Kenyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya "Kenya")  runner  [Paul Ereng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Ereng "Paul Ereng"), leaving Cruz with the silver medal. Troubled by  [Achilles' tendon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_tendon "Achilles' tendon")  injuries, Cruz was never again able to reach the international top level. In 1993, he tried to make a comeback and started over 1500 m at various Grand Prix races in Europe but failed to make a major impact. His last victory of significance came in the 1500 meters at the  [1995 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_Pan_American_Games "1995 Pan American Games"). One year later, taking part at his third Olympics at the  [1996 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics"), Cruz was the Brazilian flag-bearer and ran the 1500 meters without reaching the finals.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-5)

Cruz was a torchbearer and lit the flame cauldron at the  [2007 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pan_American_Games "2007 Pan American Games")  in  [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), on July 13, 2007. After retiring from competitions he became a running coach at the Olympic Training Center in  [Chula Vista, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chula_Vista,_California "Chula Vista, California"). He guides[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-6)  Lea Wallace,  [David Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Brown_(parathlete) "David Brown (parathlete)")  and  [Shaquille Vance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaquille_Vance "Shaquille Vance"), among others.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-brown-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-vance-8)
